July 9th, 1997																	 Dear John, 	Glad to hear from you and learn something about the situation of job-hunting in Britain. And I will try to make a vivid picture of this situation in China for you.	As far as I know, this situation in China is quite different from what you've heard about. Those methods of being automatically allocated jobs by the goverment [fm1,-] have been out-of-dated. After the economic reform and the opening-door policy, we are now having less [aj3, 1-2]and less state-run factories, but more and more joint venture [np3, 1-] and foreign fund [cc1, 2-1] company [np3, s-] . As a result, school and college leavers are having more job opportunities and they no long feel satisfied about the old methods. Now they have a double-track [fm2, 1-] methods. They can either find a job themselves in the job market or choose to be appointed by the government according to their own will. But it's not easy to find a good job because more people having recieved [fm1,-]high education, which makes job-hunting full of competetion [fm1,-]. [sn7,s]Moreover, many jobs require working experience . So things are hard for them.	In a word , the situation in China and Britain are more or less the same. Now we have just 2 years to prepare for this competetion [fm1,-] and we must try hard so that we can find a good job in the future.																Yours,Yuonne

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ?1/21eDear Mary,	I'm glad to have received your letter of 5th, July. Since I'm not well informed of the situation of the job market, I just tell you what I know as much as possible.	In China, the situation of job market is not so good. Nowadays, Chinese school and college leavers are not all automatically allocated jobs by the government. After graduation, most of the leavers must find jobs themselves. Even before graduation, a lot of students go to the job market and try to "sell" themselves. Since there are a lot of competition, it is not easy to find a job. Young people in China do have problems in finding work [wd3, 1-].	Comparing [vp2, 1-] the situation in Britain, ours is not optimistic. There is a recession in some fields of the economic [wd2, 1-], and many workers lose their job. This puts much more pressure on the graduates. Like the graduates in Britain, Chinese university leavers worry about their future.	I do hope your brother can find a suitable job before long.																	Yours, Meilisa

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ???	Since China has a large population, she also encounters a problem of unemployment. Every year, a number of undergraduates are pushed to the job markets to compete for their positions. Nowadays the system of allocating jobs has been out of date since the number of applicants greatly outstrips that of the vacancy [np6, s-] for [wd5, 1-1]jobs. So those who lose the competition will have to change their direction.	Some superior [wd7, 1-] may be given posts to choose in accordance with his own will. Others need to find their jobs by themselves. Many chances are provided as long as you are competent. If you couldn't [vp6,s-] seek a job in a year, your case will be transferred to your local personnel Department which will arrange job [np6, 1-] for you. Or if you consider that you need to receive another kind of study so as to suit the situation, you can look for some nightschools or career schools. 	Finding a job is not so easy today. Our government is trying hard to provide more jobs. I think things would [vp6,s-] be better in future.

So people have to compete with others in order to enter a good company. If you want to find a good job, you must have not only high quality, but top quality. Otherwise, you will have to find a job inferior to others [np4, 1-]. On the other hand, governments do allocate jobs for people. There are so many poor area [np3, 3-] in our country. They need to be constructed. If people are willing to work in these areas, the government can arrange work of [wd3, 3-] them.	I think you have had some brief knowledge of the job situation in China, and I hope that your brother will find a job soon.																 Yours,												         He Yupeng

They make the best use of their efforts to fight with each other in order to earn jobs. Some get jobs through their relatives or friends , some even go to the "back door" . <ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ?3/4y															July 9, 1997 Dear Billy,	I am glad that I have the chance to tell you something about how the graduates from university and school find jobs in China.	As you mentioned, it was true that school and college leavers are [vp6,s-] all automatically allocated jobs by the government in the past. In China, the intuition [wd7, 1-1] fee was paid by government, therefore, the government has [vp6,s-] the right to assign jobs to the graduates. You may find out the drawback of the system, that was [vp6,s-], the graduates always were not assigned the suitable jobs according to their situation. Things are changed by educational reform [wd4, s] recent year [np6, 3-]. Now, students pay for their study themselves and they determine their jobs themselves. Graduates enter the job market to find jobs according to their qualification and situation. Since more and more people can offer the intuition [wd7, 1-1] fee, graduates have heavier social pressure, one is that they face fiece [fm1,-] competition for finding a job, the other is that the jobs are not adequate. Finding a decent job is more difficult than [sn4, s]usual. And this forces students work harder to meet the need to [pp1, 1-] society and win in the job-hunting competition. I think it is a good tendency.	I hope what I say above can help you understand the situation in China. And if you have any question, do write back to ask me . Best Wishes [fm3, 1-2] to You.															Yours Sincerely Scarlett

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ?aD??t															July, 9, '97Dear X ,	So glad to hear form you and I am pleased to answer your questions.	You've heard that Chinese school and college leavers are all automatically allocated by the government. It used to be true. But it belongs to the past now. In order to meet the market's actual need, the Chinese government now let [vp3, 4-] the students choose their favorite jobs and accordingly, give the comanies [fm1,-] a chance to select suitable pannels [wd7, 1-] they need. Though this policy enable [vp3, 1-] job hunters and companies to be satisfied with each other, the more and more competitive job market makes the situation harder and harder. There are too many job hunters while too few chances. [sn7,s]If you are a college undergraduates [np6, 2-], it will not be too hard to find a relative satisfying job as long as you try your best. But if you are an unskilled person, or have not received much education, it will become very hard to find a good job. And the situation seems to get harder and harder in recent years.	Owing to the harder situation, we , Chinese college students, have to study very hard in order to have a higher [aj1, 1-1] chance to get a good job after graduation.	Well, have to stop now. Looking forward to hearing from you.															Yours Morley

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ?a?3/4Dear friend,													July, 9, 1997	In reply to your questions mentioned in your last letter, I would put them [pr1, 1-] this way.	Talking about the situation of employment in China, I would have to say it is no better than [wd6, -1] than in Britain. Workers in state-owned enterprises used to be regarded to have the most secure jobs in the world. But with the opening up policy and economic reforms going on, Many unprofitable state-run factories were included in the closing-down list. Few of their workers can go elsewhere but home. My mother used to an accountant in a state-run factory, [sn8,s] but now she is employed at home as full time housewife because the factory came to the an end. Generally speaking, workers are aboundant [fm1,-] now in the job market.	With such big climate, the opportunity to find a job, especially good job is not [wd3, -1] optimistic. It is even worse for a college leaver. It is true that college leavers used to be allocated a job by the government. But it is a thing of the past. Nowadays the college can only give recommedation [fm1,-] to certain companies, whether you can get it depends on your competitive capital [wd7, 1-]. Without excellent qualification, it is hard to find a good job. It is not uncommon that what you have learned will not fit in your future job. It is also not uncommon that you have to wander around the job market for some time before you find a suitable job.	Dispite [fm1,-] this situation, it is true that if you have attractive qualities, a lot of good jobs are waiting for you .	I hope have [vp9, -1] give you some ideas with regard to your questions.																	Yours.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ? ? 	When college students in China graduate, they used to get their jobs assigned to them by a certain official department. And so students could avoid the trouble of finding a job. But they also had their troubles. Chances were that they might not like the jobs they were assigned to and sometimes they might even be assigned to a job which was not suitable for their expertacy [fm2, 1-]. It sometimes could happen that a student majored in chemistry was alloted [fm1,-] to a trade company to do business! This kind of assignments, of course would not satisfy either the students or the employers.	But things have changed now. Students nowadays will not be alloted [fm1,-] a job when they leave schools. Instead, they will go into the job market and apply for the jobs which they like . In this way of 'Mutual [fm3, 1-] selection", both students and employers can freely have their choices and both can be satisfied.

E95 Class2 The English Department Guangdong University of Foreign Studies Huangshi Road The People's Republic of China July 9, 1997Dear Lily:	I'm glad to receive your letter, [sn9, s] today. Different from the situation in Britain, most unemployed people age 40--50 in China. [sn8,s] Because [wd6, 1-] due to the open-and-reform policy, China has developed extremly [fm1,-] fast recently. Many old factories had to close down because of the lack of advanced techology [fm1,-] and well-educated workers. So the old people without special knowledge had to be fired. But it was [vp6,s-] not the case in young people.	Compared with the college students in Britain, China [wd2, 1-] college leavers are luckier. Nowadays, not all the students are automatically allocated jobs by the government [sn9, s] just some of them, such as students at normal school, are allocated by the government. We ourselves have many choices depended on our own will. [sn8,s] The system which we undertake now is called "bi-choose [fm2, 1-]" system. That means we can choose the companies, and the companies can come to school to choose students as well. If a student was [vp6,s-] not chosen by a state-owned enterprise, he could [vp6,s-] go to find a job in a private-owned enterprise.	Of course, we do have some problems, for example, there are more and more graduates now. [sn1,s]But I'm sure after the government's reform policy is put forward, and if I really have quality, finding a job after graduation is not so difficult.	I do hope your brother can find a satisfactory job in the coming future. I'm looking forward to his good news. Good Luck!															Yours, Daphne

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ?o	As far as I know, young people in our country are facing no lesser [aj3, 1-] problems in finding jobs than those in Britain. Nowadays jobs are not easy to come by because of the large number of college graduates and the comparatively small number of vacant positions.	Here in China job assignment for college leavers is arranged in a mutual-choice way. It is hoped that students themselves can find suitable jobs of their own choices in the first place. Either they go to job markets to hunt work they see fit, or they go through connection to secure a lucrative job. Therefore, jobs acquired this way usually agree with the wills and interests of the college leavers. Then if a college graduate fails to get a job on his own, the government will be responsible for allocating a job for him. More often than not the student is assigned back to where he has come from, and it's not up to him to decide which work unit to go into in this case. Such is the job-seeking situation in China. I hope it can be of some help to you.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, 3????															Chen Yue Min English Department 9502 Guangdong University of Foreign Studies P.R.C. July 9, 1997Dear friend, 	I received your letter recently, and I would like to tell [vp1, 1-] as much as possible what I know of the present employment situation in China. College leavers have to find jobs on their own, while at the same time companies can choose potential employees freely. <ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ?	For many years, when China was still applying planning economic system, most of the school and college leavers were automatically allocated jobs by the government. At that time, the students needn't worry about their future at all. But at the same time, people had no chance to choose the job they were interested in, they had to take the job they were offered. Most of them were sent to the state-run factories or companies and sticked [wd7, 1-] to their positions for the whole life.	However, things have changed a lot when China began to carry out marketing economic system .The government release [vp6,s-] the responsibility of finding jobs for graduates. Since more and more private companies and joint-ventures are established, people have more opportunities to choose the jobs they like. Even reforms have taken place in state-run factories, people can not stay for all his [pr1, 1-] life due to this abilities [wd7, 1-]. So more and more young people find difficulties in job-hunting , especially those who have low-education and no experience. Even those who have found a job have to worry about how long they can keep their work.

Most of the college leavers will go to job market to look for a job, or get a job through relationship [sn6, s] and relatives.	Nowadays, it is more and more difficult to find a job. Grade II, Class 4, English Faculty, Guangdong University of Foreign Study Guangdong, China, July, 9, 1997.Miss John , Brown Room 104, Main Street London, Britain. Dear Joan,	How are you ? I'm very happy to receive your letter. You asked me about the job opportunities and situation in China. I hope I can be of some help to you.	In the past, Chinese school leavers were all automatically allocated jobs by the goverment [fm1,-]. But it's not the case nowadays. Automatically allocating jobs has caused a lot of problems. On the one hand, students are allocated to the position they are not suitable to. Their ability can't be fully reflected [wd3, 1-]. On the other hand, companies can't get the people they really need. So, since 1980s, the government changed the way. Students can have two ways to find their job. The government and schools will recommend some suitable students to the companies. At the same time, students can go out to look for job themselves. The students can have their own choice on what kind of job they want to do.	In this way, both companies and students are satisfied. But you know, with the development of the economic situation and education level, there are more competitions in the society. Some university students can't find jobs and have to stay at home. Therefore, it is still true in China [wd4, s]you can earn a living if you are qualified. Job applicants are encouraged to improve both knowledge and practical ability.	In general, the unemployment for young people is not so serious in China. If you have more questions, you can write to me. I'd be glad to help you.																Yours, Card, Shan

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ?a*1/4                           July, 9, 1997Dear friend,	I'm glad to have this chance to exchange our views on job-seeking condition in our countries. I don't have any experience about job-seeking [sn9, s]so I have to answer your question according to what I read in magazine or what I learned from my friends.	In 1980s, nearly all the graduates were all automatically allocated jobs by the goverment [fm1,-], no matter whether they liked or not. The choice for them were [vp3, 1-] very rare. As a result, more and more youngsters complained about their jobs and this policy. To solve this big problem, in 1990s, many job markets appear [vp6,s-] in our countries [np6, 1-] . Graduates can take their chance in these job markets. Some top students can be recommended by their school directly to some big companies or govenmental [fm1,-] branches. While I have to say nowadays Chinese young people are facing increasingly serious problem [np6, s-] on job-seeking because of big population and less [np8, 1-] post [np6, s-]. A large number of skilled or middle-aged workers lost their jobs for economic depression or self disadvantages. They become the contesters [fm2, 1-] of young people. Our society can not offer more post [np6, s-] to both workers and young people. Although I am still two years away from graduation, I begin to worry about my future.	Ok! If you have any questions please write to me and I'm pleased to answer them. Please remember me to your brother and wish him good luck.                             Yours,                              Rachel

July 9th, 97Dear Betty,	I'm glad to receive your letter.	Since you're interested in employment situation in China, I'm going to tell you something abut [fm1,-] it.	In the past, the graduates from universities and colleges were usually allocated jobs by government. Actually, most of the graduates were quite satisfied with their future jobs. However, there were still some of them not satisfied who would rather not go to the units but look for another [wd3, 1-] ones.	Now, things has [vp3, 1-] changed. In accordance with the market access system, graduates have to hunt jobs themselves. Thus, competition arises [sn9, s] people are supposed to show their ability to be employed. This is sure to do good to our country's economic development. [sn8,s]	Generally speaking, young people do not have many problems finding work [wd3, 1-] in China. China is carrying out the open policy, which cause [vp3, s-] a lot of joint-venture companies appear. Both domestic companies and joint-venture companies need more labours [np5, 1-] and capable people. These factors [wd3,ss-] provide graduates with more job opportunity [np6, s-].	Still, some young men find it hard to get a job, because they have a lot of demands towards jobs. They want to find a high-salaryed [fm2, 1-] and good-welfared [fm2, 1-] job, which of course is a bit difficult for them to achieve success. [sn8,s]This kind of job is very popular and everyone wants to get it.	Well, do you have some idea now? I'm ready to answer your question if you are still not very clear about it.	With my best wishes.																Yours, Jocelyn

Class 4, Grade 95 English Department Guangdong University of Foreign Studies Guangzhou, China July 9th, 97Dear Lisa, 	I'm glad to hear from you. In your letter, you talked about the situation of finding jobs in Britain. Now, I'd like to recount the situation in China.	Years ago, Chinese school and college leavers are [vp6,s-] mostly automatically allocated jobs by the government. Things have moved quickly in recent years. The situation is not the same as before. It tends to become more and more difficult to find a good job for the school and college leavers. Why is it so? Every year, a large number of students graduated [vp6,s-] from schools and found jobs, but the retirement rate can not reach the fast increasing employment rate. [sn8,s]Most companies or authorities are fully flocked with people. The competition of finding a job hits every graduates [np3, 1-].	Nowadays, it's more popular for graduates to find a job themselves through all kinds of channels rather than wait to be assigned a job by governments. In order to get a satisfactory job, they have to train themselves. In their mind [np6, 1-], they define a new successful [wd7, 1-] formula, that is, self-quality pluses [wd2, 1-3] chances and pluses relationship. According to the formula, they pay attention to not only their knowledge training, but also catching every golden chance and establishing a good relationship in their commune. In doing so, they would have better chance of finding a good job.	All in all, in the present situation, it's not easy for young people finding work [wd3, 1-]. In order to find a job, you have to "sell" yourselves--- show your ability. That's the advice I get from the people who find good jobs. I hope you may have some idea of the job situation in China.	May your brother find a job!															Yours Vicky

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ???																July 9th, 1997Dear Jack,	I was happy to receive your letter yesterday. As to the problems of finding work, I'd like to give you some idea about how things going on here in China.	In the past few years, the government did allocate jobs for school and college leavers and they didn't have to worry about their jobs after graduation. But this sort of system had many defects as the factories couldn't get suitable talents they wanted while the graduates didn't have any choice about the jobs they were interested in.	Things have changed recently. Nowadays graduates should find jobs themselves and the factories can choose these graduates as long as this is going on under the government's direction. Naturally, this has lead [fm1,-] to a problem that some people can't find a satisfactory job immediately after graduation because of the heated competition. The situation here, however, is not that serious as in Britain. Usually these young people can go to work with the help of the district office.	Hope these [pr3, 1-] information will be of some help to you. Also hope your brother can find a job soon. Look forward to hearing from you.																																  Yours Jill

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ?	Comparing [aj4, 1-] with that of Britain's, I think, the employment situation in China is much better, at least in my part of the country. In recent years, many new areas of industry are developing rapidly, such as electronics telecommunication, etc. Thus, Many new companies have opened, and there are more and more job opportunities. For example, The graduates this year in my university claim that it's much easier to find a job this year than last year. Nearly 90% of them had already located a job before the graduation ceremony.	However, considering the ever larger number of job-finders, proper managing is very important. In China, we used to have a system of job allocation. But nowadays, it is replaced by a system of mutual choice. In this system., The schools or the government act only as a media. they arrange meetings where the prospective employers and employees may have a chance to contact with each other. The employers are than [wd5, 1-] free to select the graduates, and the graduates also have the freedom to accept or reject the job. That's why call this system "mutual choice".[sn8,s]

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ????a														Class 1 Grade 95 English Department Guangdong University of Foreign Studies 7/8/97Dear John,	I was glad to receive your letter.	As to the situation in China, I think, on the whole it is not so difficult. Because of the rapid development in economy, more and more factories, enterprises as well as joint ventures have been established. These require a large number of people. So school leavers, especially college graduates find it not difficult to find a job. However, it is not easy to find a descent one. Some people have to take up a job which has nothing to do with his major. Some even complain that they should do as a labour after graduating in a college. [sn8,s] So generally you can find a job, but it may not satisfy you. Nowadays, we apply for the [wd5, 1-] job by ourselves.	The companies, factories and enterprises, are also free to choose by themselves. So this helps both sides to get their needed choice. 	I hope I have given you some useful information and I hope your brother will find a descent job soon.														  Yours Lin Yuan Yuan

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP ?>, ?1/4?1/4?															July, 9th 1997Dear Alice,	I was very glad to get your letter of June 19th. With reference to your questions in the letter, I'd now like to tell you something about how the Chinese graduates get a job.	In the past, the school leavers were automatically allocated jobs by the government. They didn't have to spare much effort to find one. However, they had not right to choose a satisfactory job on their own. Nowadays things have changed a lot. Instead of being allocated jobs by the school and the government, the students are free to find a suitable job for themselves. Anyhow, it is not easy at all. Most of the job seekings [fm2, 1-] begin a year earlier before graduation. They write applications to the companies they are interested in and have interviews with them. If each side is satisfied [sn9, s] they sign a contract. The schools are no longer responsible for finding a job for each student, but they do make recommendations. 	This is how a Chinese student find a job nowaday [fm1,-]. If you have further questions, please write to me. Do hope your brother will get a good job soon.	With best wishes														Yours Sarah

Dragonboat [fm3, 1-] Festival	Dragonboat [fm3, 1-] Festival, celebrated on the fifth of the fifth lunar month, is a traditionalChinese festival.	It is observed chiefly [wd4, s] exchanging rice dumplings and racing boats. The most common rice dumplings are trangular [fm1,-] ones coated with large bamboo leaves [sn9, s], there are many other kinds, of course. Racing dragonboats is generally held in areas near water. Players go to their lengths to try to be the first one arriving [vp1, 1-1] the terminal, [sn8,s]while their supporters shouting and yelling for them on the bank. [sn8,s]	In many miral [fm1,-] areas, it is also a time for people to visit their relatives and friends. Children are especially [wd3,-1] pleased, for they can [vp9, 1-1] following their parents outside dressed in colorful new clothes. [sn8,s]	Dragonboat [fm3, 1-] Festival is said to be celebrated in commeration [fm3, 1-] of a famous poet known as Qu Yuan in ancient china. it is said that he drowned himself in the Milo River after his reform proposals were ignored by the [fm1, -1]empor.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ?????	There are many traditional festivals in China, one which has great meanings is the Mid-Autumn Festival. [sn8,s]	Chinese people have a long history of observing this festival. It is a time for family's reunion. On the night of 15th of August, families will meet together in the house, usually on the balcony. They sit around a table on which are mooncakes, fruits, drink [np6, 1-] , biscuits and something like. [sn8,s]They admire the brightest and roundest moon in the year---as said [wd7, 1-]---while they are talking and eating. Usually the parents will wish their youngs [fm1,-] progress, especially hope the ones who live outside and married do well in their jobs and have happy families. The youngsters will also toast to their parents' health and request them to take good care of themselves. At the moment, the families enjoy the love between [pp1, 1-1] them.	It's not sure whether the Mid-Autumn Festival originates from a folk talk, [sn8,s]but it's a very traditional one. It sets asides a time for Chinese people to reunite while busying making living outside. [sn8,s]Chinese people put great stress on the festival as well as the Spring Festival.

The Mid-Autumn Day, the night of the fifteenth [wd5, 1-] day of the eighth lunar month in a year, is one of the most important traditional festivals for Chinese people . At [pp1, 1-] that night, people honor the moon with all kinds of food, especially the [wd5, s-] fruits and the [wd5,s-] moon cakes. They bless [wd3, 1-] the fairy of the moon to bring them good luck. [sn9, s] Because at [pp1, 1-] that night, the moon is considered the brightest and roundest [sn9, s], people [fm3, 1-] appreciate the moon together , eating the delicious food. Sometimes, the adults will tell the children the fairy tales about this festival. One is that, a fairy called Chang'e fell in love with a man called Wugan and was driven away by the God. She wanted to come back to the heaven. So she asked Wugan to steal some medicine, which people ate , who could [fm1, -1]fry. [sn8,s]When the medicine was [fm1, -1]get, she took it herself. <ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, 3??o		Chinese Traditional Festival [np6, 2-] 	There are many traditional festivals in China which are interesting, meaningful and long-historied. Now let me introduce one of them to you.	It is named the Up-fight Sun Festival which is celebrated on the fifth day of the 5th lunar month. On this day people always make some dumplings filled with rice, meat and something else, which are called 'Zongzi'. In fact the 'Zongzi' are sometimes thrown into rivers to feed fishes avoiding that they eat the body of a great poet named "Quyuan". [sn8,s]Quyuan is an ancient-time man and he loved his nation deeply. But, because of his direct [wd7, 1-] advices, the king couldn't accept him and had him evacuated. Then Quyuan jumped into the 'Miluo' River on the fifth day of the 5th lunar month. People couldn't find his body and had to feed the fish. After so many years it [vp6, -1] become a custom. People will remember him for ever.	There are still other customs for this festival. For example, in south China people usually have some dragon-boat matches on this special day. Perhaps it expresses people's feeling [np6, 1-] that they do want to save the great poet 'Quyuan'.	The Up-right Sun Festival is a great, special day.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, o" 	Mid-Autumn Festival is a Chinese traditional festival. It is celebrated on the 15th of the eighth lunar month. It is said that on the moon there was a poor beauty named Chang'e, she was lonely and unhappy. Every year on this day the moon was full and she would miss her husband and relatives very much, so people made this day as Mid-Autumn Festival. It is also a day for family reunions [np6, s-].	People often eat moon cakes and fruit on Mid-Autumn Festival. There will be a family sitting together, talking and watching the beautiful full-moon [sn9, s], children [fm3, 1-] wear their best clothes and play with a lattern [fm1,-]. The lattern [fm1,-] is colorful and different. Such as rabbit lattern [fm1,-], flower lattern [fm1,-], fish lattern [fm1,-] and so on [sn9, s], it [fm3, 1-] is one of the best Chinese festivals children like best. [sn8,s] Firecrackers are also a part of the celebration, but now in many cities it is forbidden. Instead, people go out street, [sn8,s]watch the flower [wd7, 1-] latterns [fm1,-] and guess the answers of the paper on the latterns [fm1,-]. [sn8,s] It is a happy time for all the families.

[sn8,s]They all close the eyes and make good wishes in heart [sn9, s], this [fm3, 1-] process lasts normally 2 minutes. After doing this, they begin to talk and enjoy themselves the delicious moon cakes. Dragonboat [fm3, 1-] Day	Now, let me tell you another [fm3, -1] Chinese festival-- the Dragonboat [fm3, 1-] Day, which is celebrated on the fifth of the fifth lunar month.	The day is set [wd3, 1-1]aside to honor a poem [fm1,-] who loved his country deeply--Qu Yuan [wd6, 1-], who lived in the Chu State in the War Period. His suggestions were not accepted by the empire, and he was not welcome by other people, so he jumped into the Miluo River to death [wd2, 1-]on the fifth of the fifth lunar month. But the nationals loved him deeply. After his death, they made many Zongzi-- the dumpling made of glutinous and meat and something else wrapped by bamboo leaves or reads, and ran their boats on [wd4, s]river. They wanted to save him. The Zongzi is prepaired [fm1,-] to protect his body from being beaten [fm1,-] by the fish in the river.	So now, on the fifth of the fifth lunar month, people always race dragon boat [np6, 2-1] which has become a kind of sport. Firecrackers will even be welcome in this day too in some places where it is allowed. [sn8,s]And certainly, Zongzi is the most popular and commonly [wd2, 1-]feast [wd3, 1-]. They can be bought in stores, or even if you like, you can make most generally you can see is pyramid-shaped, [sn8,s] [sn9, s]but [fm3, 1-]in some countries, you can see some in long round pole shape. And their sizes are different too.	Now, I think you have more idea in [pp1, 1-1]Chinese [fm3, 1-]festival.

Chong Yang Festival	Chong Yang Festival, which comes on the ninth day of the ninth month in the lunar calendar, is celebrated on the old man [sn9, s], so [fm3, 1] , it is also known as "Honor [fm3, 1-] to the old man".	On this festival each year, people are always wanting to visit the old man, or to climb the hills.	In [pp1, 1-] that day, the whole family will go out to see the old man who are [vp3, 1-] respected, or just at home buy some presents, such as food, fruit and some routine things for [pr3, -1] them. Then, at night, the family will have dinner together.	In addition, some other people will go out and climb up the tallest hill in their city. Because, as they know, people who climb up the tallest hill, [sn9,s] will gain the best luck in the future.	In Guangzhou, the tallest hill is Baiyun hills [np3, 1-]. In [pp1, 1-] this day, especially at night, more and more people will come to the foot of the hill, starting to climb up the tallest point-Moxing Lin. Few years ago, government of Guangzhou had [vp6,s-] not forbidden to burn firecrackers, so the hills will [vp6,s-]be very noisy. However, at this moment, burning firecrackers is forbidden, so the hills are quiet.	As I know, in others [wd3, 1-] parts of China, there are many different celebrations [sn9, s], but [fm3, 1-]I think the most triditional [fm1,-] significance is to be good to the old man. Let them have a happy and healthy old life.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ???a	I'm glad to tell you something about the Chinese festivals. Now I want to talk about the Dragon-Boat Festival.	The Dragon Boat Festival is ceberated [fm1,-] on the 5th day of the 5th lunar month, and it is said that this festival is to commemorate the greatest poet [sn9, s]Quyan, who jump into the water when the governor passed him by. The people there wanted to save him in their boats but in vain, so they put some Zhongzi [fm1,-] in the water so that the fish wouldn't eat his body. From then on, the Festival [fm3, 1-]began. So now many places in South China race boats on that day and eat Zhongzi [fm1,-]. [sn8,s]	In my hometown the Dragon Boat Festival is celebrated every year. A few days before the festival the villagers will go to the big rivers to fetch their boat [np6, s-], which was put in the bottom of the river the last year. During the festival they will drive the dragon boat from village to village to bring luck to the villagers there. On exactly the day, all the boats will gather together in a big river to have a race and all the people in town will go there to watch. After the race the dragon boats will go back to their village, then a big dinner begins. All the villagers will go there to have dinner, though the dishes are not so good. It is said that if you have had the dinner you will be healthy and good luck all year long. [sn8,s]

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ?????		The Mid-autumn [fm3, 1-1]festival	the Mid-autumn [fm3, 1-] Festival, also called the Moon Festival is a traditional Chinese [fm3, -1]Festival, which is observed on the 15th of the 8th lunar month. People in China have been celebrating it for a long, long time by all sorts of events. The full moon is the symbol of the festival, for it is considered that the moon is in its brightest and fullest on that night. Legend tells that there lives a fairy lady on the moon, who will bring luck and happiness to people.	To the Chinese, the Mid- [fm3, -1]autumn Festival symbolizes reunion. People will stay [pp2, -1] home together with their families. Usually, the whole family will have their home in order, then have a big meal. In some rural area [np3, 2-] people will let off fire crackers before their feasts.	When the night sets in with the brightest and fullest moon glittering in the sky, the whole family will go outdoors to admire the moon. People also put some cakes--including mooncakes, candies, some fruits and so forth. On [fm3, 1-] a table to honor the moon. People, often chatting, laughing, singing, enjoy the moonlight together, and exchange best wishes.	Nowadays, the lantern gatherings are held in cites [fm1,-]to celebrate the festival. And they add more color to the traditional festival.

Mild [fm1,-]-autumn [fm3,1 -1] festival has a long long history. I don't know its origin. Maybe because the moon is round, which means the family reunion. Thus the festival hands [wd3, 1-1]down from generation to generation.	The Chinese think highly of the festival. The moon cake is the symbol of it. They buy all kinds of moon cakes. Most moon cakes are round, just like the moon. At some places, there are also all kinds of beautiful lanterns. This [pr1, 1-] is the happy time for the young people. They can have a romantic night with their lovers, carrying the lanterns. In my hometown, the happest [fm1,-] are the children. They sing and dance from door to door to get plenty of food to eat, such as moon cakes, candy,fruits and so on. Friecrack [fm1,-]s are not popular in the festival but a part of Spring Festival. Dragon Boat Festival	In China, there are many, besides Spring festival [fm3, 1-], fantastic holidays according to the lunar calendar, such as the dragon [fm3, 1-1] boat [fm3, -1]festival.	The dragon [fm3, 1-1]boat [fm3, -1]festival or the up [fm3, 1-1]-right-sun [fm3, 1-1]festival is celebrated on the fifth of the fifth lunar month. In [pp1, 1-] this day, racing dragon boats is the major observance. All over the country, especially in South China, people would like to have a competition of racing boats. During the racing, the contenders [sn9, s], strain at racing, while the crowds on the watersides are screaming and cheering. And there is another thing for people to do--eating dumplings which are made of glutinous rice and beans and wraped [fm1,-]with locus leaves. It [pr1,1 -]also has several flavour [np3,1-] such as sweet, savoury.	Nowadays, people observe this festival happily; but in the past days, this day is celebrated for the commemoration of the great poem [fm1,-] Quyuan. In the ancient period, the poem [fm1,-]dropped himself down to the Milo rive [fm1,-], for the empire had ignored his political reform. The people immediately went to rescue him with boats but in vain.	Though the history has passed, it is certain that the Chinese people would have the deep impression on the poem [fm1,-] when they celebrate this festival with pleasure.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, 1/2-??1/2		The Dragonboat [fm3, 1-] Festival	There is a very interesting traditional Chinese festival called the Dragonboat [fm3, 1-] Festival. It observes on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month and comemorates [fm1,-] the death of a great poet Qiyan [fm1,-], who threw himself into the Milo river [fm3, 1-]when his proposals of reform of Empire Chu was ignored by the [fm1, -1] Emporor. When people knew it [sn9, s] they drove their boats to save him but in vain [sn9, s]and they threw some rice into the river to feed the fish so that the fish wouldn't bite [fm1, -1]Qiyan's body. And years past, people threw Jongzi instead of rice into the river and that became a custom.	Nowadays, the sad day become a festival. People eat Jongzi, one kind of dumpling which made of glutinous rice and meat, [sn8,s]and race dragonboat to celebrate the festival. In my hometown, there are also these celebrations, but a little vary [wd3, 1-]from the other places in China. This festival is not a very important one in my hometown. When it comes, only some places race dragonboats and most of us just eat Jongzi to celebrate it.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ? ??	Mid-autumn [fm3, 1-] Festival, also [wd4, s] Moon Festival, is one of the Chinese traditional [fm3, -1]Festivals celebrated by all the Chinese every year. It is on [wd4, s]15th of August in the Chinese lunar calendar.	As it is observed in autumn, it has a traditional significance of consecuting [wd7, 1-] the God of harvest. that [fm3, 1-] means people held rites to thank the god [vp1, -1] of bringing them harvest. So, it is similar to the American official festival, the Thanks Giving [fm3, -1] day.	What is more, Mid-autumn [fm3, 1-] Festival also originated from a Chinese legend. In the early years, there was [wd4, 2-1] hero, named Hou Yi who always helped people in trouble and saved people from the disaster. Once he got [np6, -2] magic pill , anyone who ate it can become Saint and live in the moon. But Hou Yi's wife, Chang e had eaten it first, she flied onto [pp1, 1-1] the moon and left her husband alone. Every year, on that day, [wd4, s]15th of August, the moon turns round [sn8,s]most, the hero could see his wife in the moon clearly. That symbolized a sense of missing. And nowdays [fm1,-], Chinese people observe the Festival [fm3, 1-]with one will, hoping the whole family's reunion and safty [fm1,-]. The whole family sit in the open air, chatting leisurely, eating traditional food, [wd4, s] as moon cake [np6, 1-] (roundish cake), fruits, nuts and other products from ground, and most of all, appreciating the beauty of the moon. In such atomasphere [fm1,-], the whole world seems more quiet and peaceful, and that is an occasion [pp1, -1] of the people approaching most closely to the nature.

There are also many wonderful performances to celebrate the festival, especially all kinds of colorful lanterns on display. [sn8,s]In some places, people usually go out with relatives or friends to see the lanterns displayed in some certain places in the evening, talking, laughing and exchanging the greetings. Everywhere there is a joy of people. [sn8,s]	Sometimes, there is also a lantern riddle. Anyone who can guess the answer, such as a name of a thing, a person, or a place, will be given a prize. This game usually puts the celebration to a climax. At the same time, there will be many kinds of parades in the streets. People stand [wd3, -1]beside, watching the beautiful dressed-up people acting as all kinds of figures, sharing the cheers and happiness.	How cheerful and happy we are in the lantern [fm3, 1-] Festival. Everyone in China enjoys it. And everyone hopes each other will be lucky during the year.

Dragon Boat Festival	Dragon Boat Festival is very popular in china, which is celebrated on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month. This day is set [wd3, 1-1]aside to commemorate the great Chinese poet, Qu Yuan. He loved his country and decided to devote himself to the country. However he was denied by the King. At last, he suitcided [fm1,-] [wd4, 1-]by jumping into the river on this day. So people honour him for his integrity and love to the country.	This festival is a very happy day. On this day people will make a special kind of dumpling, which is called Zongzi. It contains various kinds of thing [np6, 1-] , rice, meat and beans ect [sn9, s], which is delicious. However, the most exciting event is racing boat [np6, 1-] on the river. People will divided into several teams and race in the boat on the river. Other people crowding on the bank will cheer up loudly even after the race ends. [sn8,s] That's why this festival is called Dragon Boat Festival.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, "???	Mid-autumn [fm3, 1-] Festival, which is also called the Moon Festival, is celebrated on the 15th day of the 8th lunar month all over the country. On that night, [wd4, -1] moon will become full and all the members of the family will come together , so it's a day of family reunion.	Mid-autumn [fm3, 1-] Festival is connected with a beautifully [wd2, 1-] sad story. Long long ago, there lived a hunter and his wife. At that time, there were 10 suns in the sky, so it was very hot [sn9,s], people [fm3, 1-]couldn't stand it and they became ill. The hunter hunted down 9 suns. People lived happily from then on. And God in Heaven praised the hunter and gave him 2 tablets which could make him and his wife lived longer. But the wife ate both, so she flew to the moon and lived there lonely. It's a punishment for her. When moon is [vp6,s-] full , she can [vp6,s-] see the earth and she feels [vp6,s-]sad.	Every Mid-autumn [fm3, 1-] Festival, all the members of a family came back home [sn9, s], they [fm3, 1-] have a big dinner, then sit around, eating all kinds of foods and talking to each other. <ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>,?o	Dragon Day is an important festival in China. It's observed on the fifth day of [wd4, -2] fifth month in the lunduar [fm1,-] year. The traditional significances [wd3, 1-] of this festival are dragon boat and zongzi.	Dragon Day is to honor the great poet Qu Yuan who lived in Impire [fm1,-] Chu in about 280 BC. He loved his country very much and was royol [fm1,-] to his nation. But the Imperor [fm1,-] Chu didn't believe him and drove him off. So he committed suicide to [wd4, -2] Miluo River. Since then, people observe Dragon Day to honor him. They row dragon boat [np6, 1-] on the river and eat zongzi which is some rice and the ingredience [fm1,-] wrapped in the bamboo leaves to make a diamond-shaped dumping. [sn8,s]	On this day, people who live near the river will get up early and go to the rive [fm1,-] watching the racing of the dragon boats . Then they are satisfied when the boat they prefer wins the racing. And every home will make zongzi that day.	Dragon Day is an important festival to relax and honor the great poet Qu Yuan.

It's a traditional festival which originated in Han Dynasty.	Usually before Lantern Festival, the members of a family will prepare a lantern together. The lantern is always made of bamboo, red silk or cloth. Commonly [wd2, 1-] people will make it ball-shaped, and put a candle or a light in. So when the day comes, they will place it exactly in front of the house [sn9, s], and [fm3, 1-] at night, they will fire the candle or turn on the light, and it gives off very bright red light. Chinese people like the colour of red very much. The [fm1,-] think the red lantern will frighten the evils and give themselves good luck. <ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ?1/2e?1				Lantern Festival	Lantern Festival, also called Yuanxiao Jie, is another typical Chinese traditional festival has a long history. [sn8,s]It was recorded that during the Han Dynasty (about 200 B.C.) people had been celebrating [wd4,s] on that day.	Lantern Festival originated in some kind [np3, 1-] of ancient ceremony praying for plenty of rains, to make the crops grow better [sn9, s], in the following spring. For Chinese peasants, it marks both the end of Spring Festival and the beginning of another planting season.	On the day of Lantern Festival, there will be all kinds of performances in the streets. Chinese operas, lion dancing, high stilt stepping parades are most common. In the evening each family will eat Yuanxiao, a kind of sweet stuffed dampling [fm1,-], which means happiness and good luck in the new year. People will also hang up some lanterns around their house, usually red, quite big and with some Chinese words on [pr3, -1] it. Lanterns symbolize the hope for [wd3, 1-]every person in the family : health and safety. In some places it is also said that the more lanterns people hang up on Lantern Festival, the more thriving the family will be.

But the origin of the festival was a rather sad and moving affair. It was about a [np7, 1-] ancient poet Qu Yuan who loved his country so much that he jumped into [wd4, s]river and killed himself after his reform proposal had been ignored by the empire and his country was finally defeated. People adored him so much that they rowed dragon boats to look for his body. After failing to find it, they made many rice dumplings in order to feed the fish in the river and protect his body from being eaten. <ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, *1/2 ??				The Dragon Boat Festival	The Dragon Boat Festival, also called Upright Festival falls on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month in China. The day is set [wd3, 1-1] aside for commemorating the death of the great patriotic poet. Quyuan, who threw himself into the Miluo river [fm3, 1-] because the king refused his advice of reform. People observe the Dragon Boat Festival by dragon boat racing and eating glutinous rice dumpling [np6, 1-] . It is said that the dragon boat racing and its origin in the people's attempts to rescue Quyuan and that dumplings were thrown into the river to feed the fish in case they ate the body of the poet. [sn8,s]People living near rivers and big lakes can organize dragon boat races on the day. Usually about ten people dressed in some traditional costumes sit in one dragon boat, which is brightly painted. In the process of the race, one person on each boat hits a drum to keep the pace of roaring and inspire his colleages [fm1,-]. There may be thousands of people on shore to watch the exciting scene. Glutinous rice dumpling is a kind of food which has the shape of a pyramid with glutinous rice wrapped in a special kind of leaf. There are all kinds of dumplings on sale around the [fm3, -1] Festival. People usually eat them with their families.	The dragon boat race and glutinous rice dumpling have become symbols of the Dragon Boat Festival.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ?T o?	Dragon Boat Festival has a long history with dragon boat race and zongzi (glutinous rice dumpling in the shape of a pyramid) as its symbols. It falls on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month and people observe the day to commemorate the death of Qu Yuan, a patriotic poet in ancient China, who drowned himself in River Milo on this day more than 200 years ago. At that time, people tried to rescue him by rowing boats though in vain. And from this originated [wd7, s] the tradition of racing dragon boats although it is now practiced merely for fun. the [fm3, 1-] traditional food of this festival is zongzi which people make and exchange with friends and relatives. It is generally wrapped in bamboo or reed leaves and rich in variety as regards shape and fillings. As it needs a rather complicated and time consuming--process to make, people nowadays prefer to buy zongzi from restaurants. [sn8,s]

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ??		Lantern Festival	Lantern Festival is a traditional festival in China. It's said that people in acient [fm1,-] times celebrated this festival in honor of the ceremony of preying for rain for their spring plough [wd2, 1-]. Nowadays, when Lantern Festival comes, the 15th day of the first lunar month, people celebrate it with a programme [fm1,-]of different games and performances. In my hometown, people like to hang up the lanterns at home during the festival. They think the more lanterns they hang up, the more prosperos [fm1,-] and happier their families will be. Sometimes people write some riddles on the lanterns and ask people to guess. Whoever gets the answer will be given a bowl of sweet glutinous dumplings, which are the traditional food for Lantern Festival. Besides hanging the lanterns, some adults are [vp7, 1-1] sometimes disguised as lions by wearing the costumes made of cloth and wood. These "lions" dance, jump and say "Happy New Year" to the people. Some other people, especially the men, wear the women's clothes or are [vp7, 1-1] disguised [fm1,-] as the fat babies dancing [sn8,s] following the "lions": You can also see some of them walk on the high stilts. [sn8,s] It's very interesting, isn't it? Now, in the 20th century, people in China celebrate Lantern Festival maily [fm1,-] for fun and family reunion than commemorating the ceremony of preying for rain.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>,	There're many traditional festivals for Chinese people, Spring Festival is the most important of all. But Mid [fm3, -1]-autumn [wd4, s] is also another important festival.	Mid- [fm3, -1]autumn [wd4, s] ( Zhong qiu jie ) is also called Moon Festival. It falls on the 15th day in the 8th lunar month. It's believed that the moon will become brightest and fullest on that very night. People will get together and worship the moon. There's also a legendary story about the moon: a lady stole and took her husband's medicine which would make people forever young, then she suddenly could fly. She flew to the moon and stayed there alone with a rabbit ever since. This story is always told to children. To celebrate Mid- [fm3, -1]autumn [wd4, s], people usually ate a kind of typical food called mooncake. It's full moon-shaped and stuffed with peanuts, walnuts and many other ingredents [fm1,-] and it tasted [vp6,s-] very sweet. Autumn is a harvest season, so there are various type [np3, 1-] of foods served on that day.	Nowadays, Moon Festival is usually a family gathering and have a feast. Especially in big cities, people have no more chance to worship the moon because of the tall buildings and the bright lights. Still people regard it very important.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ??D?	Yuanxiao Festival, or Lantern Festival, is celebrated on the fifteenth day of the first lunar [wd3, -1]calendar. It is said that people celebrated this festival as early as during [wd3, 1-] Han Dynasty and that it originated from the rain praying ceremony before spring plowing in ancient time [np6, 1-] . However, people nowadays observe it as the last day of their family reunion during Spring Festival After the day they begin going out to make a living again.  People celebrate Yuanxiao Festival with eating Tang yuan ( sweet dumplings made of glutinous rice flour and symbolizing reunion ), hanging up lanterns, putting on various performances and playing games.	 These days people seldom hang up lanterns in their house, but they still perform various programmes, among which lion dancing is the most interesting and widespread. It needs two men to do the job: one handles the wooden lion head and acts as its fore legs, the other acts as its hind legs. The "lion" leads the other members of the lion dancing team, who dress up in false beards, or [wd4, s] as women or fat children. They go from door to door, the lion jumping, bowing and rolling on the ground, to wish people a good new year. Usually families being visited give some lucky money to the team.	Apart from the lion dancing, guessing lantern riddles is another popular game played on Yuanxiao Festival. Lantern riddles are those written on pieces of paper attached to the lanterns. The answers may be a word, a line of a poet [fm1,-], a person's name, a place's name or an object's name. Those who figure out the answers are rewarded on the spot. It is so much fun that people, wearing their new year's clothes, go from here to there trying to find out one that they know the answer of. [sn8,s]	When Yuanxiao Festival is over, in the Chinese' s point of view, the Spring Festival is also over and another new year is [vp7, 1-1] begun.

The young men will attend the race while the children will swim near the bank. Because it is said that the water of dragon boat will bring you good luck and make you healthier. [sn2,s]	The Gragon [fm1,-] Boat Festival is in the mid-summer. People just wear short clothes. But different colours of the umbrallas [fm1,-] and caps they carring [fm1,-] and the flags and flowers on the dragon boats make the festival more colourful. After the drgon [fm1,-] boat race., people in a [wd3, 1-] same village will sit together and have a "dragon boat [wd7, -1] meat". It means the whole village is united. This reflets [fm1,-] the importance of "union" to the Chinese people.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ????"a		The Latern [fm1,-]Festival	Yuan Xiao Jia [fm1,-], also known as the Latern [fm1,-] Festival, falls on the 15th day of the first month in the lunar calendar. It is said that this festival was observed after the rain-praying ceremony in ancient China. Nowadays people celebrate this day by eating tan [fm1,-] yuan ( sweet dumplings made of glutinous rice and symbolizing reunion ) and hanging up laterns [fm1,-]. The number of the laterns [fm1,-] they hang up is determined by the number of a family. And the more laterns [fm1,-], the better, for it is a blessing for a family to have numerous children.	People observe this festival with a large variety of games, such as stilts-walking, drum-dancing and lion-dancing. Among those games, lion-dancing is the most interesting and widespread one. With a lion, handled by two persons, dancing, rolling or bowing in the front, and a lot of people dressed up as animals or fat children following behind, people greet and wish each other a happy new year.	Another well-known game is guessing riddles, which are glued on the laterns [fm1,-]. The answers to them are either a person's name, an object's name or a place's name. The person who gives the right answer is rewarded on -spot.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, *3/42T		Mid-Autumn Festival	Mid-autumn [fm3, 1-1] festival is one of the most important Chinese traditional festivals. It is on the fifteenth day of the eighth lunar month.	It is said that the moon in [pp1, 1-] this day is the roundest. People celebrate the day by admiring the full moon while eating moon-cake. Moon-cake is the food ate in Mid-autumn [fm3, 1-1] festival. Its shape is like a full moon. Inside the cake there is some nuts or egg yolks.	The significance of this festival is to celebrate the union. Family members, friends or even couples who live apart will have a happy gathering on this day.	The moon is bright and round. People are chatting to the dearest person while eating sweet moon-cakes. These make mid-autumn [fm3, 1-1] festival a happy and warm festival.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, Y	Dragon boat [fm3, 1-1] holiday is observed on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month. Originally, the purpose of celebrating it is to commemorate a famous ancient Chinese poet who is loyal to his motherland. But nowadays, it has much to do with entertainment than with the poet. People make dumplings on that day. And in my hometown these dumplings are different from the ones we make for Spring Festival. They are just glutenous [fm1,-] dumplings and when you eat it you must dip it into sugar water. People also have dragon boat races on that day, because it is said that when the antient [fm1,-] people knew the poet dalting [fm1,-] himself into the river, they had tried to resecute [fm1,-] him by boat. Dragon boat races are the focus of the holiday. Thousands of people will gather along the riverside and cheer for their favorite boat teams. You can hear drums, cheerings, [fm2, 1-] fire crackers and applauses [np5, 1-] during the whole race. And the prize for the race is a small roasted pig, which symbolizes wealth and lucky.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ???		The Lantern Festival	The Lantern Festival, which falls on the 15th day of the first lunar month, marks the end of the Chinese New Year celebration and the beginning of a new year's work. ( for the preasants [fm1,-], this means to plough. ) In [pp1, 1-] this day, people will put on their beautiful clothes and make merry. [sn8,s]	In my hometown, as in many other places, the family will gather [wd4, s] and eat "Yuan Xiao" ( glutineous [fm1,-] dumplings stuffed with sugar, sesame, etc. ) which means " reunioned [wd2, 1-] of the family and the "sweet" life of the new year. 	Children will be very happy, for they will be given a beautiful lantern with which they will go out at night, playing firecrakers [fm1,-], watching fireworks and having some "lantern [wd3, -1]guess". The "questions" will be put on lanterns hanging [wd3, -1] high, if anyone gets the right "answer", he will be rewarded.	In some other places, lanterns will be hanged [wd4, s] to indicate the prosperous life of the family. The number of the lanterns depends on the number of the family.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, o?*1/2		Lantern Festival	Yuan Xiao Festival, also called Lantern Festival, which falls on the fifteenth day of the first month of the lunar year, marks the end of Chinese lunar new year celebrations . It is observed around the country and it is a day for family gathering. People celebrate the day by hanging up lanterns at night and eating Tang Yuan ( some round balls made of sticky rice flour with varied [wd2, 1-] fillings inside. ) which symbolizes union and happiness. Games like riddle guessing are also played on that day. The special thing about riddle-guessing is riddles are written on the paper ribbons attached to the lanterns. Those who get the right answers can get their prizes immediately. In some places, people put [wd3, 1-1]on parades and performances like lion dancing, donkey dancing, drum beating, etc.	Traditionally, the Lanter [fm1,-] Festival is also a day for lovers as Valentines day is in some western countries.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ?TD???		Clear Bright Festival	Clear Bright Festival, which is on the fifth day of the fifth lunar month, is to commemorate an antient [fm1,-] poet, Qu Yuan. He killed himself by jumping into the Mi [wd4, s] River after his advice for the goodness [wd3, 1-] of the country was rejected by the king. On this day each year, people usually have dragon-boat races in the sound of drums. [sn8,s]Because it is said [wd4, s] after Qu Yuan committed suicide, people sat in boats, hit the drums, and tried to find his body in the Mi [wd4, s] River but in vain. And they threw many Zhongzi, which are glutinous rice dumplings, into the river to feed the fish to prevent them eating Qu Yuan's body. Today, people also eat Zhongzi [fm1,-] on Clear Bright Festival. Nowadays, Clear Bright Festival is also a day to show respect to war-time heroes and ancestors. People let off firecrackers and put flowers on the tombs. Clear Bright Festival is now more a day to have boat racing and eat Zhong [fm1,-] zi than to commemorate Qu Yuan. People are happy instead of sad this day.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ???			The Dragonboat [fm3, 1-] Festival	The Dragonboat [fm3, 1-] Festival falls on the fifth day of the fifth month on [pp1, 1-] the lunar calindar [fm1,-].	Nowadays, it's more a day for fun than a day to commemorate Quyuan, who was a patriotic poet. People observe the day with all kinds of performances. The most widespread custom is boat racing. In Guangzhou there is boat racing on [pp1, 1-] the Pearl River every year. Lots of people go to watch the race at both sides of the river. Besides boat racing, there is a kind of special food for that day. People eat Zongzi (a kind of pyamid [fm1,-] dumpling made of glutinous rice, with peanuts, egg yolks and port in it). It's very delicious. Some people make Zongzi themselves at home, others may go out to buy some from restaurants.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ????			Mid-Autumn Festival	Mid-Autumn Festival is celebrated on the fifteenth day of the eighth lunar month [sn9, s]., Chinese people regard it as an important festival because it symbolizes the reunion of the family. And there is also a romantic fairy tale about the festival. A beatiful [fm1,-] lady was forced to leave the heaven by the god and had to live on the moon with a rabbit. The moon on the night is considered to be the brightest and the biggest. On the night, after a rich dinner, the family members gather and admire the full moon. They eat moon cakes (a round cake with eggyolk inside) and fruits while talking, and stay up a bit later than usual. Nowadays, rich TV programmes and fireworks display bring people more fun.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ????"?				The Lantern Festival	The Lantern Festival , whose Chinese name is Yuanxiaojie [fm3, 1-], falls on the fifteenth [wd4, s] of the first lunar month, only two weeks after the Spring Festival.	On that evening, there will be a lot of beautiful lanterns on display either along the streets or in front of the houses. The lanterns are made of coloured paper and bamboo. They symbolize luck and happiness to the Chinese people. There're lanterns of all sizes, shapes and colors. People would go out to appreciate the lanterns and enjoy the wonderful performance, such as the lion dancing, high stilt walking, drum dancing, fireworks displayed and so on. The lion dancing is the most [fm1, -1]populous. It consists of 2 people to do that. One would carry the head of the lion which is made of wood; the other would carry the tail, which is made of colourful cloth. The lion can jump, walk and dance. Children dressed in new clothes, would play firecrackers in the streets or in the parks. There are also some games for people to take part in.	The traditional food of the Lantern Festival is yuanxiao, a kind of sweet dumplings.

People also send drumplings [fm1,-] to other family members and friends. At [pp1, 1-] that night, all the family members would share a feast and, of course, the dumplings, talking and laughing. That's the Dragon Boat Festival.

Dragon boat [fm3, 1-1] festival	Dragon boat [fm3, 1-1]festival is one of the most important traditional holidays in China, which is celebrated on [wd4, -s] 5th May according to the lunar calendar. It's a day to abserve [fm1,-] the great acient [fm1,-] poet Chuyuan [fm1,-]whose reform proposals were ignored by the king and threw himself into the Miluo [fm3, -1]river. At that time, people gathered boats in the river to look for him, but tried in vain. Ever since that , on [wd4, -4] 5th May every year, people make zhon [fm1,-]zi, a kind of piramid [fm1,-]-shaped dumpling wraped [fm1,-] in bamboo leaves, and throw them into the river so that the fish won't eat the poet. And it becomes a custom to race dragon boats in rivers. Nowedays [fm1,-], people don't throw zhonzi [fm1,-] into the river, they eat it instead. And dragon boats are raced in every big city where there is a river.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ? ??				the Spring Festival	In China, there's another calendar, the lunar calendar. So, Janurary [fm1,-] 1st in the lunar calendar, is maybe in February. At that time, the Spring Festival comes. We celebrate it for nearly half a month. <ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ???			Dragon Boat Festival	 [wd4, s]Dragon Boat Festival is one of the most famous Chinese Traditional [fm3, 1-1]Festivals. It is celebrated on the 5th [wd4, s]of May in Lunar [fm3, 1-1] Calendar every year. At first, it is memorized Quyuan, [sn8,s]who jumped into the Boluo [fm1,-] River for showing his love of the nation, by the people since Waring [fm1,-]-states poried [fm1,-]. [sn8,s] Nowadays, its traditional significance is to have [wd3, 1-] no floods or dryness in a whole year, have a good hartest [fm1,-] and have a good living condition. People usually hold a dragon boat competition in [pp1, 1-] the day of [wd4, s] Dragon Boat Festival. In the competition, people try their best to drive the boat fast to win. The team which wins the competition, it will bring good luck to them. [sn8,s] After several thousand years, this kind of activity is held as a kind of sports [wd7, 1-1] champion all over the world. Besides Chinese people, all the other people from other countries take part in this old sports. We also eat Zongzi on that day. Zongzi is a kind of tradational [fm1,-]food. It is made of glutinous rice, stuffed with much [np8, 1-] tasty indigrents [fm1,-], such as meat, beans, peanut, dry [wd2, 1-] shrimp [np6, 1-] and so on. [sn8,s] The Chinese traditional Festivals [fm3, 1-] are getting well-known by [wd3, 1-] foreigners.

It is also a day for the whole family relatives and friends to gather together. [sn8,s]So, when [wd4, s] mid-autum [fm1,-] Festival comes, people who stay far away from their families will always try their best to go back to their hometowns to meet their families, and those [sn9, s], who will not be able to go back, will always miss their families most on that night. She felt very lonely, for [sn9, s], the only friend of hers on the moon was a rabbit. So, in [pp1, 1-] Mid-Autum [fm1,-] night, she would come out and people could see her strolling on [pp1, 1-] the sky gracefully. 	But nowadays, [wd4, s] Mid-Autum [fm1,-] Festival is more a day for [fm1, -1] gethering, relaxation than a day for admiring the moon. Maybe, it is because that people in nowadays, have less and less patience to admire the moon quietly.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ?*3/4?	 [wd4, s]Pure Brightness Day, on April 5th, as [wd3, 1-] Memorial Day in U.S.A. is also a traditional festival to pay our respect to the dead in China.	That day, the whole family will gather together and climb up the mountain where their family's graves lay and sweep them. [sn8,s]  First, the adult will sweep the graves such as cutting off the grass which grow [wd3, -1] unregularly the previous year and shaping the graves. Then, people will put some food, chicken, meat, wine, in front of the graves and light candles and burn paper money. [sn8,s]  Firecrackers will be also lighted to give out deafening noise which is said to call the dead back to enjoy the food and to receive the living's respect. Childen [fm1,-] are often asked to kneel down before [wd4, s] graves to kowtow to ask for the dead's blessing. While the aduts [fm1,-] only bow making wishes. [sn8,s] After this, all the people present can eat sugar cranes [fm1 -] which mean [vp3, 1-] to bring you a sweet future life, and enjoy the beautiful scene of the mountain. 	In some supertitious contrysides, women are not allowed to take part in the ceremoney and can only stay at home preparing dinners. But now, it changes a lot. The festival is treated as a family reunion, and it's a happy day more than a sad day. Children can get close to the nature and learn more about the past generations.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ???t	Besides the Spring Festival, the Mid-Autumn Festival is another important traditional Chinese festival. <ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ??1/2-?3				Duanwu [fm3, 1-] Festival	Different places have different forms to celebrate [wd4, s] Duanwu [fm3, 1-] Festival. It is also called [wd4, s] Dragon-boat [fm3, 1-] Festival. Now I will tell you something about the festival in my hometown.	According to the lunar calendar Dragon-boat [fm3, 1-] Festival happens on May 5. There are two steps to celebrate the festival. The first step consists of honoring ancestors, eating Chinese dumpling [np6, 1-] and eggs, and putting up ai -- a kind of grass. Honoring ancestors are [vp3, 1-] to put Chinese dumpling [np6, 1-]and eggs or some meat on table to the front of one place to honor ancestors. [sn8,s] Then we let off fire-crackers. After that we must put up [fm1, -1] air--a grass) fixed on the door, but I don't know why to do so. Perhaps it will bring good luck. Only when the first two thing [np3,2-] have been done can we eat dumplings and eggs. But now we don't mind that we can eat them before the celebration. The second step is to go to a temple to honor the saints and also go to the river to watch dragon-boats. Dragon-boats have a tale to save QuYuan, [sn8,s]the hero of the acient [fm1,-]China. But now we only watch the race for fun. Now in the square near the temple and river there are many sellers to sell goods to people. So many of [wd5, 1-] people on that day always ask their parents for money to buy some clothes or other goods.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ?1/4? Dragon Boat's Day	Dragon Boat's Day is a tradictional [fm1,-] Chinese festival. <ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ?? ??				The Mid-Autumn Festival In China	The Mid-Autumn Festival is another traditional festival in China. It is on the 15th night on [pp1, 1-]the eighth lunar month.	It is a time for family reunions like the Spring Festival. [sn8,s]On that night, people have festive dinners, the symbole [fm1,-] of the festival---moon cakes and lots of fruits. Lanterns are hung up to add some atmosphere. Children play with them [pr1, 1-] around home for fun.	It is believed that the moon at [pp1, 1-] that night is [wd4,1-3] brightest and roundest, and people admire it. There is a beautiful legend too. It is about a [np7, 1-] ancient lady named changer, who ate the elixir and became a fair lady flied to the moon. Then she felt lonely and missed home much. So poets in ancient China usually wrote poems about her and the homesick.	Nowadays, more and more people send thire [fm1,-] greeting to overseas Chinese with moon cakes and let them feel people here also miss them much.	Up to now, the Mid-Autumn Festival is more a time for reunions than a celebration for harvest.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ?a?(c)?		 Ghosts' Day	Ghosts' Day is called "Chinese [fm1, -1] Halloma" by some foreigners. In China, the ways to observe the day is different from place to place. Children that day are quite different from the American children who observing their Halloween [fm1,-]. They are warn [vp7, 1-] by all kinds of terrible stories and they will be much more quite [fm1, -] than usual. [sn8,s] At night, the family members gather together and the old ones would advise the youngest to be good guy [sn9, s], and [fm3, 1-] what they eat that night is quite good and they will also prepare some dish [np3, 1-] for the ghost outside. In a words [pp2,2-], the people will be more serious that day than usual.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ??1??	Here I'd like to tell you about the Dragon Boat Day. It is also called "Double 5th Day".	 [wd4, s]Dragon Boat Day is celebrated on 5th, 5th in lunar [fm1, -1] callendar. It's [np4, 1-4] traditional significance is to memorize a famous writer, Qu yuan , who lived about 2,000 years ago. It is said that he loved his motherland very much and wanted to work for it. But he had no chance, because his king didn't believe him. At last he committed suicide by jumping into a river called Miluo Jiang on 5th, 5th in the lunar [fm1, -1] calledar.	Appreciating his loving motherland, people make the day of his death a festival and on that day, people make a lot of dumplings and throw them into the river in order to prevent the fish from eating Qu yuan. And of course, people themselves eat the dumplings, too. People also have races of running dragon boat in the river. At that time, a lot of people gather along the river to see the performance. The [wd6, 1-] race is very exciting. And it is also the reason that we call the festival " Dragon Boat Day".	But Nowadays [fm3,-], people celebrate the Dragon Boat Day more for exciting than for memorizing Qu yuan's death.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, 3?"Y		Mid-Autumn Festival	Mid-autumn festival is in [pp2,-7] the 15th of the eighth lunar month. It is an important festival for families to reunite. Chinese people prize is very much. [sn8,s] Although some people work far away from their hometown, they will always return to celebrate it with their families. In Chinese people's eyes, reunion is the most important symbol of [wd4, s] Mid-autumn [fm3, 1-] Festival. At [pp1, 1-] that day, we have a festive dinner with our families and then make some pastry to eat. When night draws [vp2, 1-], we go up to terrace to wait for the moon. We usually put a table in the middle of the terrace, then pop [wd7, 1-2] a platter on it, with all kinds of fruits, such as apples, pears, bananas, tomatoes, moon cakes, pastry. And we also burn incenses and plunge them into a kind of rounded [wd2, 1-] fruit. We are very happy at [pp1, 1-] that night. We sing, dance, play games and let off firecrackers. And some young people spend the night barbecuing, holding party, singing outside their home. And this kind of abservance [fm1,-] is becoming more popular.

<ST 5>, <SEX ?>, <Y ?>, <SCH GIFL>, <AGE ?>, <WAY 1>, <DIC 2>, <TYP 2>, ???o?	I'm glad to hear from you. There'll be a lot of Chinese traditional festivals. I'd like to tell you, but this time, I would first tell you one of them- [wd4, s]Dragon Boat's [fm2, 1-] Day, which is celebrated on April 1st in lunar calendar.	Dragon Boat's [fm2, 1-] Day originates from the ancient China. It honores [fm1,-] a very famous person in China--Qu Yuan who loved his country very much and died for it. The first celebration of the festival was to drop the dumplings made of sticky rice. It means they were the food for Qu Yuan who dived into [wd4, s] Milou River and died. Later, [fm3, -1]Since people did this by boat and the form of commemoration changed. Now, there will be Boat Match on the day everywhere in our country. The Boat is so called "Dragon Boat".	There's a river ( the pearl river ) runs across Guangzhou. [sn8,s]We used to hold "Dragon Boat Match in the river every year by individual. In recent years, the match has been held by the government establishments of the city and the match is becoming international. The government will invite boat teams of many countries to take part. Maybe you have heard of this, however, the teams of our countries will just keep the Chinese traditional style. They wore the clothes of national style, that is a cloth surrounded the head. A white clothes without sleeves and a clothe belt circling the waist. They are boating as some of them playing Chinese style instruments. The scene is very interesting and stimulating.	I think I have told you the main details of the festival. I hope you'll come to see the celebration next year.
