<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 21><WAY 3><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                  Ladies and gentlemen, attention please!  Each person is innocent until [wd4,5-3]  is proven guilty.  No, we should not say this boy is a criminal until he is proven guilty.     Now let's settle the reasonable doubts in this case.     Above all, let's talk about the old man's witness [wd3,6-] . His apartment is right under the apartment where the killing took place.  His bed is by the window.  It's twelve feet from his bed to the bedroom door.  The hall is forty-three feet, six inches long.     Suppose when he heard the body falling he got out of bed, got his canes, walk [vp6,8-]  twelve feet, open [vp6,10-]  the bedroom door, walk [vp6,13-]  forty-three feet, and open [vp6, 16-]  the front door, saw the boy running downstairs.  How long did he [pr1,s-s]  take?  He said fifteen seconds.  However, he is so old that he only walks very slowly and even helped [vp7, 7-2]  by others into the witness chair.  So, his remark [np6, 1-2]  is doubtful.  I had demonstrated [vp6,2-6]  once, which took me thirty-nine seconds.     Secondly, that knife is also an important witness [wd3,s-] . His father was stabbed with this knife.  I had searched [vp6,2-5]  that area and found that quite a few second-hand shops sold it out [wd5,s-] .  We can't say it was the boy who committed the murder.  Someone else who helds [fm2,-]  it may did [vp4,6-1]  it.    Besides, this boy is five feet eight inches tall.  His father was six two.  It's hard to stab down the chest of someone who's taller than you are.  It's also a considerable [wd3,3-1]  point.     Thirdly, let's look at that woman's witness [wd3,s-] .  At [wd5,-2]  that night, she went to bed about eleven o'clock.  Her bed was next to the open window, and she could see right into the window across the elevated trains.  After tossing and turning for an hour, she turned toward the window at about twelve ten.  Then she saw the killing through the window of a moving train.     Now, I want to mention something about the EL train.  It has five cars.  When it passes a given point, it lasts ten seconds, or two seconds a car.  So, the train had been going by the old woman's window for at least six seconds before the body fell, according to that woman.  That old man said he had heard [vp1,2-3]  the boy shouted "I'm going to kill you."  while the train was roaring past his nose.  It was so noisy that everybody could not hear it. Maybe the old man was lying or he thought he had heard it.     Furthermore, let's look at that woman.  She saw the murder through the window of [wd4,3-3]  last two cars.  I put in a word, do you notice that she wore glasses when she was at [wd3,3-1]  court?  So when she slept, she didn't wear glasses as she said.  Suppose she put the glasses near the bed, the murder was taking place as she looked out.  The light went out a second later, she couldn't had [vp4,2-6]  time to put on her glasses.  Maybe what she saw was only a blur.     Now, as you can see, these two eyewitnesses' remarks have so many considerable doubts.  What they spoke [wd3,2-3]  was not fit[wd3,-] for the murder on the spot.   So according to the facts I mentioned, I think this boy is innocent. 

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 2>                                                                      SAY SOMETHING ABOUT JANE EYRE'S CHARACTER    Jane Eyre, written by Charlotte Bronte (1816--1855), is a world-famous masterpiece.  After reading it, what impresses upon my mind most, is the leading role, Jane Eyre's resistance[cc1,-1] spirit. This characteristic runs through all Jane's life. We can see it by her words, her thoughts and her actions.        In this novel, Jane's experiences can be divided into four parts: at Gateshead, at Lowood Orphanage, at Thornfield and at the River's .  Jane's character is embodied in these experiences gradually.         Jane lost both her parents at an early age.  She was brought up at Gateshead, her aunt's house, where she was looked down upon and ill-treated by her aunt and cousins.  In such a condition Jane's resistance [cc1,-]spirit showed [wd3,-]little by little. Here we can see two high ideas [cc4,2-] .  One is when she was beaten by her cousin John, she called  out to him, "Wicked and cruel boy!" "You're like a murderer -- you are like a slave-driver -- you're like the evil rulers of ancient Rome! " For a child relying on her relation [wd3,3-2]  for life, it takes much strength and courage to say those words.  The other high tide [wd3,4-]  is: The night before Jane left Gateshead for Lowood, she gathered all her energies and spoke out those words to her cruel aunt, "I dislike you the worst of anyone in the world, except John Reed." "If anyone asks me how I like you, and how you treated me.  I will say that...you treated me with miserable cruelty."  Such words from a ten-year-old little girl! Even the cruel woman "look [vp6,3-1]  frightened"        In Lowood Orphanage, the life conditions were very hard.  Jane and her companions received forments [fm1,-]  not only in body, but in mind .  She once said to Helen Burns, a friend of hers. [sn9,-]   "When we are struck without a reason, we should strike back very hard."  Striking back very hard!  Not willing to be oppressed!  That's Jane Eyre.        After 8 years' life in Lowood Orphanage, a wild desire for freedom came over Jane.  She hoped for a new condition.  She was willing to be accepted as a governess at Thornfield .  There she met the master of Thornfield, Mr Rochester.  They understood each other and were attracted [wd4,2-2]  each other.  They intended to marry [vp7,s-] .  But things were going on difficultly.  Here Jane Eyre's resistance [wd2,-1]  spirit showed fully.  For example, when Jane learned that Mr Rochester had intended to marry Miss Ingram but still wanted her to stay at Thornfield, Jane called out, stirred to something like passion.  "Do you think I am a machine without feelings?... I'm not talking to you now by the standards of custom and the world. It's my spirit that addresses your spirit, as if we stood before God, equal, as we are!"  It's because Jane put emphasis on "equal" that she left Thornfield when she learned at the wedding that Mr Rochester had married fifteen years ago and his mad wife was still alive .  Jane felt she was cheated.  She must defend dignity of her own!     It was a hard time for her after she left Thornfield.  She ad no money.  She had no job.  She nearly died...But she wouldn't be regarded as a beggar.  Then she was accepted by the River's Family.  There her fate changed.  Her uncle left her all his property.  She learned that the Rivers were her relations.  But Jane still, or even strongly thought of Mr Rochester. [sn8,s] She refused to marry his [pr1,4-1]  cousin, for she didn't love him.  Because of the strength of love, Jane returned to Thornfield, to find it had become a blackened ruin.  And Mr. Rochester had lost his see-sight [wd3,5-]  in a fire.  But Jane married him and they led a happy life.    Such is Jane Eyre, a woman who has resistance [wd2,-1]  spirit, a woman that has strong desire for freedom and happiness! 
 
<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                           PRIDE AND PREJUDICE; WORTHY OF THE NAME     Most readers agree that Pride and Prejudice is a masterpiece.  A famous American literary critic thought that Jane Austen, the author of Pride and Prejudice, could even be compared with Shakespere.  After reading the novel myself, I find that it is really worthy of the name -- one of the world's ten masterpieces.    Someone thought Jane was both a moralist and a humorist.  These, I think, are embodied in Pride and Prejudice fully.     To [pp2,-3] the author's opinion, such marriage as is based on money and beauty is unhappy.  Like Charlotte and Collins, Charlotte married Collins only because she was old enough to marry, only because she had to find an "insurance box " for her food, clothing and shelter.  Now let's see Lydia and Wickham. Lydia loved Wickham because he was a handsome man, wearing military uniform.  What did they get after their marriage? "His (Wickham's) affection for her soon sunk into indifference: hers (Lydia's) lasted a little longer....she retained all the claims to reputation which her marriage had given her."     On the contrary, Jane's and Elizabeth's marriages are based on love.  Whether Elizabeth and Darcy or Jane and Bingley, they paid more attention to the other's quality than other sides.  So they were happy all the time.     From the comparison, we can naturally draw a conclusion: Whether it is a happy marriage or not depends on whether they love each other and whether they are perfectly suited to each other.     After reading the novel, I can't help saying that it's a perfect satire.  It often made me into an awkard [fm1,-]  position.            Mrs Bannet was a very funny character.  The only thing that worried her was how to marry her daughters to a rich man [np6,s-] .  She believed that "a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of  a wife."  Whenever she met a wealthy young man, the most important thing for her was to find out if he had got married or not.  Let's see her funny reaction when she heard that Mr Bingley was still single.  "Oh! single, my dear, to be sure!  A man of large fortune...What a fine thing for our girls. "  As if she was sure that Mr Bingley would be her son-in-law. [sn2,s-]   Because such thoughts were filled with [pp1,1-2]her heart, she was angry, annoyed, sad when she learned that Mr Bingley had left without asking Jane to marry him; she was excited, exalted after she had married three of her daughters.     Now let's have a look at that proud Mrs. Catherine. In order to prevent Darcy and Elizabeth's marriage, she became rather active.  She first went a long way to threaten Elizabeth, then went to scold Darcy.  What was the result?  It actually helped Elizabeth and Darcy clear up the misunderstanding.  How funny and interesting!  I couldn't help applauding when I was reading this part.     In a word.  I like the novel very much, not because what other people say, not because of its fame, but because I really enjoy reading it.
  
<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                             MY OPINION TO THE THREE MUSKETEERS     Alexandre Dumas is famous as a French writer.  He made his mark on two novels.  One is Monte Cristo, and the other is The Three Musketeers.     The success of the Three Musketeers lies in many sides [wd3,s-] , but I think the most important one is that it models [wd3,-3]  many characteristic figures.  For example, D'Artagnan and the three musketeers, Athos, Porthas and Aramis.    D'Artagnan, a young Gascon, was a determined, brave and intelligent man.  I draw the conclusion from the following three events.  The first is that D'Artagnan and his three friends vercame [fm1,-] many difficulties, broke through the dense nets made by Ricbelieu (The Cardinal) and got back the diamond which was a gift to the Duke of Buckingham by the French queen.  And this led to the failure of Ricbelieu's evil plan and protected the king and queen from being attacked by Ricbelieu.  The second is how D'Artagnan fought against Milady, the Cardinal's secret agents.  And the third is connected with the attack  against the port of Rochelle.     Actually, D'Artagnan is an adventurer, "without regret for the past, confident in the present, full of hope for the future. "  Even his opponent thought highly of him.  The Cardinal, for example, thought "his (D'Artagnan's) activity, his courage, and his understanding" were important to a good master.  And at last, the Cardinal made a wise decision, appointing D'Artagnan the officer of the Musketeers.     D'Artagnan gradually proved himself to be a perfect musketeer, which was his greatest wish.  What's more, during the course of fighting, D'Artagnan won the friendship of Athos, orthos and Aramis, the three Musketeers.       Athas, a man of his word. [sn2,s-]   He was very frank to friends.   He was calm and methodical.  We can see his intelligence from these two examples.  When the other three were just going to drink the anjou wine, which was actually sent by Milady with a forged letter, Athos said, "Do not let us foolishly drink wine from an unknown giver."  The facts proved him right.  The wine was poisoned [wd3,s-] .  One more example, he forced Milady to give him the paper the Cardinal signed, which read, "It is by my order and for the good of the state that the bearer of this has done what he has done."  it protected D'Artagnan from being put into prison after their execution of Milady.  In a word, Athos was a man of wisdom.     Porthos, though a little vain-glorious and boast [wd2,s-] , was a brave soldier.  He had a lot of shortcomings and was not as bright as his friends, but he fought with his friends side by side and never gave up.     Aramis, who was called the scholar and future monk by his friends, was also a determined man.  Many times he played an important role.    There are still many other characteristic figures in this novel.  For example, Milady and the Cardinal.  The three Musketeers is a lifelike picture of France from about 1625 to 1628.  

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                                             WHAT I THINK OF REBECCA    After reading VANITY FAIR, Rebecca impressed [cc3,-3]upon my mind most.      I must say that Rebecca was a woman of selfishness and cruelty.  She became ruthless in her methods for the purpose of getting into the upper society.  She even hurt Amelia, a gentle, tender-hearted woman, the only one who was really kind and friendly to her.     She envied Amelia because in her opinion, everything seemed to smile on  Amelia's fortunes.  "Her fortune comfortable settled, I have only myself and my brains to trust to [vp1,s-].  Well, let us see if some day or other I cannot show my real superiority.... only it will be a fine day when I can take my place above her in the world."  Bearing such feelings in her heart, she began to make plans for the future.     At Amelia's home, Rebecca met Amelia's brother,  Joseph.  He was rich and unmarried.  Having learned this, Rebecca was determined to conquer him.  She pretended to be very much interested in India because Joseph was in the East India Company's Civil Service.  She swallowed her feelings when she was played joke on by Joseph's father.  She just looked forward to Joseph's proposal, but it didn't come.  And Rebecca had to leave and take up her post in [wd4,1-2]  Crawley family.      There she determined to strengthen her position with the Crawley family by making friends of [vp2,3-1]  everyone who could at all interfere with her comfort.  In order to win the heart of Miss Crawley, a rich old lady, she did every kind of service.  Once Miss Crawley fell ill, Rebecca "spent as weary a fortnight as ever human beings could, in the old lady's ickroom [fm1,-], but her little body seemed made of iron."     During the time in [wd4,1-2]  Crawley family, Rebecca conquered Captain Rawdon Crawley and after their secret marriage, they ran away.  Rebecca made use of Miss Crawley's name as an introduction to society.  Maybe she thought herself successful.  In a famous ball given in Brussels,  Amelia and Rebecca were both present .  "While Amelia's appearance was a complete failure.  Mrs Rawdon Crawley's entrance was on the contrary, dazzling. ...Everyone looked at her.  Numbers of the men ...crowded round her, begging for the honour of a dance."  She greeted Amelia and began to talk in a superior way.  "She criticized both her dress, and her hair."  This happened after Amelia's father became a ruined man, and at that time Amelia had been married for about a week.  It was in this ball that Amelia's husband was struck by Rebecca, which was too much for Amelia to bear.     Rebecca's "success" didn't last  long.  Her husband could not bear her and left her.  And she also lost the love of her on, younger Rawdon.  She wasted her property and got a dreadful reputation. Rebecca, once a "successful" woman, became a wanderer in Europe. Unfortunately, Joseph, Amelia and Major Dobbin met with Rebecca again.  And Joseph, once more, was struck by Rebecca's beauty and became almost entirely her slave. Joseph's illness was daily increasing and died leaving one thousand pounds for Rebecca.  The younger Rawdon refused to see his mother, but allowed a generous income.  Amelia and Dobbin refused to communicate with her.  Rebecca seemed to spend her time working for the church.  That's the end of Rebecca's fate.      We have the right to blame Rebecca, but from the story we can also see that Rebecca was a person [wd3,s-] , too.   In many scenes, she and Amelia, one was in earnest and the other a perfect actress. [sn2,s-]   But she felt some pricking of conscience for her behaviour towards Amelia, the kind and simple friend who had been the first in life to defend her."  Actually, she did something helpful to Amelia in removing the bar between her and a new affection.  In this sense, she helped Amelia and Dobbin.     Therefore, I think Rebecca could have become as kind a person as Amelia.  But she didn't.  Why?  Let's see something about her early experience.     She lost both her parents when she was 17.  And at school she was treated "worse than any servant in the kitchen".  She was very clever and thought herself "a thousand times cleverer and more charming than most of the rich girls".  But she had no money, no good position.  So she got ill-treated and looked down upon.  Because of all these reasons, she went on a road leading to wealth and fame.     Rebecca's experience is a reflection of the society.  At the end of the book, there is a paragraph going like this,"  Ah! Which of us is happy in this world?  Which of us has his desire, or, having it, is satisfied? " In that society, fame, power and wealth are everything.  "Gratitude among the rich is scarcely natural."  We can imagine the life people without fame, power and wealth lived, in such a society.  So, I think, while we are blaming Rebecca, we might, or should sympathize [vp1,1-1]  her. 

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 2>                                                                                                   David Copperfield     David Copperfield, six months before he was born, his father died.[sn,s].   His mother married another man, who treated cruelly to [vp1,3-3]  him and his mother.  David's mother was a ind-hearted [fm1,-] but weak-kneed woman.  She was completely under the control of her husband.  Apart from tears, she could not do anything.  "Those who liked me did not dare to show it; those ho did not, showed it so plainly that I felt I always appeared o be anxious and dull at home. "  Here  Those [fm3,-]  who liked him: referred to Peggoty (David and his mother's servant), besides his mother.  Peggoty was a good woman and loved David deeply.     David's stepfather was so cruel that he sent David to Salem House.  The owner of the school, Mr. Creekle, was the sort of man who thought it a pleasure to punish his students.  He ordered David to put a notice "Be careful.  He bites."  on his back.  What a shameful thing for little David! "No one knew how much I suffered wearing that piece of cardboard."  It was not long before David learned  the news that his dear mother had died!  We can imagine how much David suffered!     Later, his education at Salem House ended and the cruel stepfather sent him to work at a business in the wine trade.  That place was almost a ruin.  He felt all his hopes of growing up to be an educated and respectable gentleman was destroyed.  He felt ashamed of his situation and he felt hopeless for his future.     Finally, David decided to run away from the tiring place and the tiring days.  He managed to find his only relation in the world, his aunt, Miss Beccy.  This was the most important event in David's life.  With his aunt's support, David entered a school where he was well taught and well-treated.  Again with his aunt's help, David became a lawyer at Spenlow & Jorkins.    Not long after that, David's aunt was ruined.  So David intended to find a job in addition to his work at Spenlow & Jorkins.  He worked as a secretary and got a good salary.  Later he was determined to learn to be a reporter, because he had learned that "many important and  successful men had worked as reporters for newspapers when they were young"  He worked hard for it and learned the art of being a reporter.  Meanwhile, David won an ideal marriage at last.    After going a long way and fighting a hard struggle, David Copperfield achieved his aims both in career and family.     David's story, like a long line, runs through the whole novel.  From the experience of David and the people around him, we can have a clear idea of the society of his time.  The bourgeoisie was greedy and hypocritical.  The hard-working people were living a miserable life.  To show it more clearly,  I'll talk something about the Peggotty family, and Uriah Heep, another figure.   David became a friend of the Peggotty family through his dear servant, Peggotty.  This was a completely make-up [wd3,-1]  family.  Mr. Peggotty, a generous man, supported the family.  He cared for two orphans, Ham and Emily.  Another member was Mrs.  Gummidge, the widow of Mr. Peggotty's partner in a boat.  They loved each other.  But they were often in trouble because they had no money. In spite of working hard, they could not change their fate.  It owes to the society, I think.   Of all the figures in this novel, Uriah Heep was among those who impressed upon my mind most.  I think we can't find any words better than "a wicked devil" to describe him.  He took advantage of Mr. Wickfield's weakness while Mr. Wickfield was fairy [fm1,-]  kind to him.  By a trick he became Mr Wickfield's partner in the business and took a lot of money. He made Mr. Wickfield completely controlled by him and did dishonest deeds by taking Mr. Wickfield's name.  Fortunately, he was found out and was punished.    From the comparison, we can see the two opposite world of that time.  And the story of David's success encourages us to struggle, never to give up.  I think this novel is attractive and instructive.  It makes me think a lot.  The writer, Charles Dickens, also preferred this novel.  He once said, "This is my favourite one of all my works."  

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                      A Man Can Be Destroyed But Not Defeated     This is the sentence that impresses upon my  mind most after I read the short novel, The Old Man and the Sea.  Actually, I'm deeply moved and encouraged by it.     The Old Man and the Sea  is a story of a Cuban fisherman in the gulf stream and the giant Marlin he kills and loses.  At the beginning of the story, the old man had gone eighty-four days without taking a fish.  The other fishermen, either made fun of him or were sad about him.  He was considered "salao", which is the worst form of unlucky.  However, he himself never lost the confidence and belief.    The body of the novel is about how the old fisherman fought against the nature to catch the big fish.  He spent three days and two nights at the endless sea, without salt and such necessities, without company and only talking to himself, the fish and the birds.  Moreover, his hand was cramped, bleeding.  He was not only fighting against nature, but also fighting against himself.    His words and actions show us what sort of man he was. "If he (the fish) stays down forever, then I'll stay down with him for ever"  What a patient and firm man! "  I wish I could show him what sort of  man I am.  I wish I was the fish, with everything he has against my will and intelligence."  In face of danger, he remained, or became calmer and stronger!  He himself said he was an old strange man".  But the sentence "A man can be destroyed but not  defeated."  is the exact explanation of his deeds.  because he had the firm belief in his mind, he was so brave, so strong, so optimistic!   After reading the novel, I sank into deep thought.  Someone says that The Old Man and the Sea  is not only a novel, but a fable about human being's life as well.  I strongly think so.  The deepgoing theme of the novel will have an effect on anyone who reads it.     In our everyday life, we will meet with so much difficulty. It's hard to avoid.  The most important thing is how you look on it and how you deal with it.  Some people lie down as soon as they see the shadow of difficulty, but others not. [sn2,s-]   Like the old fisherman, they fight bravely against the thistles and thorns.  They never give up halfway, never lose hope and confidence, never take[cc3,-4] their fate lying down.  Such is the true an who would rather be destroyed than be defeated.    Life is not easy for everyone.  There are always obstacles to overcome.  There is constant struggle.  To fight bravely is the only way to get through.  If one doesn't try, he will never have any chance to succeed.     The above is my impression and poor opinion [cc4,2-]  on the novel, The Old Man and the Sea. 
                                     
<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                             After Reading Alice in Wonderland      Alice in Wonderland   is a world-famous reading material for children.  Being a college student, I might seem a little childish to read it.  Some of my friends laughed at me, "This is not a book for us.  It's only written to cheat the little ones." However, I don't agree with them.  After reading the book.  I'm deeply attracted by its rich imagination and naturally-shown theme.  And I think these  are the two necessary attributes for a successful story.    The story starts with Alice's falling into a dream because she didn't like the book without pictures in it . To young children, interest is the best teacher.  How can the authors make children show interest in their stories?  The essential aspect, I think, is that the story must be interesting and imaginative enough to meet the needs of children's curiosity.  lice in wonderland   is really a book full of fantastic imagination.  In the story, we can imagine the cat that disappeared in an order of tail, body, head and at last his grin.  A grin without a cat is really funny.  We can also create an image of an egg with two eyes and a nose and a mouth, the ends of whose mouth would meet behind the head when he grinned.  And I think the children will admire Alice because she could control her size by biting the left or right side of a mushroom.  How great it is!  Surely the children will be absorbed into [vp1, 2-2]  the story as they read it.  They will follow Alice's steps and find a new and unusual wonderland.     Nowadays, some people criticize cartoons saying that they limit children's imagination.  Everything has its advantages and disadvantages.  Compared with cartoons, interesting books play a more important part in making children imaginative and creative, I think.     Things that were instilled in our minds during our most impressionable years (when we are [vp6,14-2]  still children) will not be easily forgotten.  Just think back.  I'm sure nobody will deny that stories have had a deep effect on us.  The moral lessons we learned from them affected, is affecting and will affect all of us.  Therefore, a really successful story should have an instructive theme, without violence, without hatred, without sex. At this point, Alice in Wonderland  is also a successful story.    Alice treated equally on [vp1,3-3]  all the animals she met, he rabbit, the cat, the mouse, the caterpillar.  She helped the three gardeners.  If it had not been for her, they would have been killed by the Queen.  The Queen  was a boastful and cruel woman.  She was very much authoritarian, who often called out "Off with his/her head" without any reason.  But Alice wasn't frightened.  She spoke out what she wanted to say," Who is afraid of you?  You're only a card from a pack."  She didn't fall down on the Queen's face.  When she learned that the Duchess boxed the Queen's ears and was thrown into prison, Alice thought it funny.  In a word, Alice always behaved herself politely, kindly and friendly, but she never bowed to authority. Children will learn these good characters gradually as they read the story and thus the story leads children to a proper way.      The above is my opinion of a successful story after reading Alice in Wonderland.  And this book, because it's very interesting and instructive, becomes very popular all over the world.  It's a great success.  I therefore think, before the writers begin to write reading material for children, they should bear the following principles in mind -- to be interesting and instructive.  

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                           Wrong Dreams     Everyone has a dream.  Without dreams, we would be lowspirited and the world would be dull.  But what will happen to a person if he/she has wrong dreams?   Death of a Salesman tells about the tragedy of such a man, whose name is Willy Loman, Willy firmly believes that he can become famous and wealthy on [pp1,-2]his personality. He works as a salesman for Wagner Company for as long as 34 years, with dream in mind,  But things go by contraries.  Not only has he never been well-known or rich, but also he is fired by his boss for the reason that he is too old.  Willy is lost, but he still cannot get out of the hell of his wrong dreams.  He finally commits suicide, still with the dream of fame and fortune, for he believes that his son will get $20,000 insurance for his death, thus become rich.  Wrong dreams!    If you want to analyze the tragedy of Willy, you will naturally think of its background.  Willy Loman is an ordinary American citizen living in the early 1800s.  It was a time when Dream of America -- everyone except the laziest ones can gain ame and fortune through hard work in our society" was so popular and wide-spread.  As it turned out, a large number of Americans suffered from it.  Willy Loman is a typical figure of that time.     We now know clearly that "Dream of America" is an unrealistic illusion, a deceitful progaganda [fm1,-] .  Willy's tragedy is unchangeable, on one hand, because of his own weak personality [sn9,-]on the other hand, because of the political, [sn9,-]and social conditions. Under the condition of capitalist developing [wd2,5-]  it is inevitable for the whole society to divide into two opposite group [np6,2-]  and the difference between them tends to be larger.It is impossible for every citizen to be rich. On the contrary what the majority lose is exactly what the minor capitalists get. The capitalists accumulate their fortune by means of exploiting the working class.  There is no way to avoid the contradiction in that society.     In that kind of society, some people live a luxury life without working whereas some are in rock bottom even if they work their head [np6,2-1]  off.     Such is the condition of society.  The purpose of declaring that everybody can be rich through hard work is only to find an excuse to cover the cruelty and guile of the capitalists.      But numerous Willy Lomans fell into the dream and never got out of it, thus numerous tragedies took place.  At the end of Death of a Salesman, only Biff, Willy's elder son, realizes that "He had the wrong dreams", while others still firmly believe in the dream.  That's the most miserable tragedy, I think.  

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 2>                                                                                         Waterloo Bridge   Roy walks over Waterloo Bridge.  He comes forward to [wd3, 4-1]  rail, looks down to [wd3,3-1]  water thoughtfully, removes his gloves, takes an ivory charm from his pocket, and holds it in his hand.    Roy sinks into deep thought.  Twenty years!  Waterloo Bridge is still Waterloo Bridge.  The good luck charm is still in his hand but Myra will never appear as twenty years ago,    Twenty years ago, just on this Waterloo Bridge, Roy met Myra for the first time and they fell in love with each other at the first sight. That evening he gave up the Colonel's dinner and made an appointment with Myra.  Though Roy had to go to the front the next day, he was quite optimistic to meet Myra again, while Myra was more or less pessimistic.  Just as Myra was upset about Roy's leaving, Roy went to see her and asked her to marry him, because he had 48 hours' leave.  Everything was going on so wonderfully.  Myra agreed and he easily got the consent of Duke. except one thing, when they got to St. Matthew's, the time for marriage  had passed.  It will never do any harm to wait just a few hours, but who will imagine that the orders suddenly changed.  Roy had to go before their planned marriage.     That leads to eternal regret.  Life was terribly hard to Myra.  She was dismissed and couldn't find a job.  Moreover, she accidentally saw the name "Roy Cronin" in column headed Fallen Officers!  Desperately, Myra became a whore to make a living.        However, Roy didn't die and returned after the war ended.  e as beside himself with joy to see Myra at the railway station.  He decided to marry Myra as soon as possible.      Myra's heart was full of contradictions.  She deeply loved y and the love was so pure that Myra would never do anything to stain it.  But she had been ... a whore! Roy was born in a noble family.  Myra painfully found that the differences between her and Roy were like a concrete wall and there was only one road before her.  Only death could prove that the love between Roy and her was loyal and pure.     Roy went to look for Myra anywhere he could think of, but he would never find her.  Only Myra's purse and its contents scattered on Waterloo Bridge.    Now twenty years have passed.  Now Roy, as a Colonel, will again go to the front -- The Second World War has broken out.    Roy's face is full of pain and resentment.  Is it just because of the loss of Myra?  I think it has deeper meanings.  Though Roy doesn't say anything, his expressions are saying his feelings silently.  Inwardly Roy is sure to have wanted to speak out, "Detestable war!  Hateful World!" 

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>     the [fm3,-]  Pursuer for[wd3,-] Equality     After reading Jane Eyre, I found that the main character of the novel, Jane Eyre, is a pursuer for [wd3,2-1]  equality.     Even as a child, Jane felt mistily that equality meant so much to her.  She struggled to leave her aunt not only because she was badly treated, but also [wd4,-]she found herself far away from the equality between her and her relations.[sn8,s]    In her aunt's house, Gateshead, she "has less right than a servant."     Although Lowood Orphanage had a much worse living condition than Gateshead, the equality that had been given to Jane strongly attracted her.  She lived an active life there and managed to gain other's respect.  She decided that "in spite of the hardness of my life,  I would not have exchanged Lowood for all the comforts of Gateshead."       Did Jane give up to pursue equality when she was employed by Mr. Rochester?  No, she didn't.  That is why she felt very pleased when she came to know that Mrs. Fairfax was a housekeeper instead of a great lady and the equality between them was confirmed.  That is why she first respected her employer and then loved him.    Altogether, Jane Eyre has [vp6,2-11]  an iron will to pursue equality, which made her more admirable. 

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                                           A Successful Novel                       ---- Tess of the D'urbervilles    Tess of the D'urbervilles telling the story of Tess, is a successful novel that can make the readers cry sadly and think a lot.    Village girl as Tess is, she is worthy of being loved by a perfect gentleman.  It is not because of her charming appearance, but because of her noble character.  She is kind and diligent and as the oldest child in a poor family, she works hard to help her parents without a murmur.  She is pure in soul nd even is ashamed of her mother's thought that the daughter should try to marry for richness; she has a sense of self-respect and never askes [fm2,-]  her parents-in-law for help even in the darkest days.    Good as Tess is, life is never fair to her.  Working hard to earn money for her family, she is seduced by a playboy named Alec, Feeling shameful and guilty, she has and then loses her own child. Dreaming of a happy, new life, she loses her sweetheart, Angel, after he knows her past. Being hopeless, she gives her body to Alec, the man she hates. Then, facing the man she loves, she does not no longer belong to herself.[sn8,s]       "Too late, too late!'  "I say, I say it is too late!"  , reading the words from Tess's broken heart, every reader will cry for her.  At last, Tess kills Alec and flees away with Angle.  They stay together alone only three days.  After the 3-day happiness, she is executed.     Poor Tess, she spends her whole short lifetime to pursue the truth and kindness in the world, but has been struck down by the evil and sham time after time until she dies.  It is with [pp1,-] this girl and her miserable life that the author exposes the evil of the capitalist society.   Without a doubt,  Tess of the D'urbervilles is really a successful novel.

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                                                   Rebecca               ------ An Example of Good Writing Technique     After reading the fascinating story of Rebecca, I appreciate the Author's writing technique very much.  It is the excellent writing technique, I think , that makes the novel so exciting and attrative [fm1,-] .    First of all, the remarkable writing technique is showed [fm2,-]  by the angle from which the story is recounted.  Without a unique angel, the story would probably have to begin with Rebecca and Maxim's life, and then it would go on telling how Rebecca cheat [vp6,7-6]  her husband, how Maxim killed Rebecca, and how Maxim remarry [vp6,7-]  , etc. Thus, there would be two female main characters in the novel and the story is sure to be dull and boring.  In fact, the smart author made a good choice of the angle.  It seems that the whole story is told by the nameless lady, who is Maxim's second wife.  The readers are made to know the truth little by little together with the lady.  Doubtless [wd2,-s] , it makes the readers be [wd5,4-3]  burning with curiosity when they are reading.     Secondly, we can see the good writing technique through the tightnit [fm1,-]  plot of the novel.  At the beginning of the novel, the big manor Manderley is revealed to the readers through the dream of the nameless lady.  After that, all the details of the story are pulled out from the lady's memory, and they are all connected with Manderley.  Rebecca married Maxim in order to be in charge of Manderley. Maxim killed Rebecca for Manderley. And things in Manderley always makes the nameless lady feel ill at ease.  At last, the story ends with the end of Manderley.  Manderley is burnt done [vp2,s-] .  Naturely [fm1,-] , with such a tightnit [fm1,-]  plot, it is difficult for us to lose the book after we open it.     The[wd5,-] third, the description of the details is also a success. For example, when Maxim told his second wife the things about the munder [fm1,-] , he said I had to get water from the bay, I had to keep going backwards and forwards for it. There was blood all around where she lay on the floor.  The window kept banging backwards and forwards..."  From the description, it is easy to imagine Maxim's hard condition: how he madly runs backwards and forwards in the pitch-dark, how he fearfully watchs [fm2,-]  the pool of blood of the dead body [wd5,7-], and how the noise of the banging window makes his fast-beating heart beat faster.  Obviously, such vivid description strenthen  [fm1,-]  the attraction of the novel.    As we can see, to write a successful novel like Rebecca, good writing technique is really important, of great help.[sn8,s]  

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 18><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                                             Wuthering Heights                   ---------A story of Revenge    It's hard to believe that love could lead to so many sufferings, but it does in Wuthering Heights.     Heathcliff is a boy adopted by Mr. Earnshaw, who was the owner of the Wuthering Heights.  Mr. Earnshaw dotes on Heathcliff very much, which causes the envy and hatred from his son, Hindley.  but Catherine, the daughter of Earnshaw is very fond of Heathcliff.    As soon as Mr Earnshaw dies, Hindley, as the new master of Wuthering Heights, begins to treat Heathcliff cruelly.  This does not hurt Heathcliff too much because Catherine's love makes everything up.    Things changes [vp3,1-]  soon after Edgar Linton, the heir to the Thrushcross Grange, falls in love with Catherine.  Catherine as to choose.  She at last chooses Edgar with the illusion that she can use her husband's proverty [fm1,-]  to help Heathcliff.  Heathcliff could not bear it and leaves Wuthering Heights.    Three years later, Heathcliff comes back with a lot of money and a heart filled with love and hatred.  He has a plan of revenge.  First, he makes Hindley a gambler and won the whole Wuthering Heights from him.  Secondly, he makes Isabella, the younger sister of Edger his wife by means of deceiving, and then treats her badly. Thirdly, he makes Hindley's son Hareton his servant and gives him no chance of education.     Catherine, with sorrow and guity [fm1,-] , dies after her giving birth to little cathy [fm3,-] .  Heathcliff's love and hatred hasn't faded away but getting stronger and stronger.    A few years later, Heathcliff forces little Cathy to marry is on little Linton, thus, after the deaths of Edger and little Linton, he gets the provery [fm1,-]  of Thrushcross Grange.    Now, Heathcliff seems to have fulfilled his plan of revenge. But the fruit of revenge is tasteless.  With the development of the love between little cathy [fm3,-]  and Hareton, grief and regret seizes [vp3,3-1]  him by the throat tighter and tighter, and then kills [vp3,13-1]  him.      This sad story of revenge tells people that we must learn to know how to love, and we mustn't let our love give way to hatred.  The power of love is great, and if you use it wrongly, you are sure to be punished by it.  

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 19><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                               That's the Way I Look at It              -- Hard Times      When I first read the novel  Hard Times,  I didn't enjoy it because there were so many characters who seemed so ridiculous to me.  I thought the author had merely created a queer story.  However, I soon realized that It [fm3,-]  isn't a right way to read the novel forgetting the whole back-ground characteristic f the time.  I should think of what time is Hard Times talking bout.     Now, I can understand the novel much better.  I divided the people in the book into three parts [wd3,9-],they represent three different types of persons in the capitalist society of [wd4,-2]  mid-19 [fm2,-]  century. [sn1,s]    Mr Bounderby and Mr Gradgrind are typical characters of the capitalists.  They only believe money and facts.  The way Mr Gradgrind educates the children and the way Mr Bounderby treats is mother may seem incredible to us, but if we analyze the social background, we will not think it has been exaggerated.  In the middle part [wd5,3-3]  of  [wd4,5-2]  19 century, the [wd5,-6]  capitalism was still in its boyhood, we call it non-monopoly capitalism. [sn1,s] And at that time, the capitalists hadn't think of [vp6,5-]  the need to cover up their cruelty yet.  So the capitalists at [wd3,-2]  those  days are [vp6,6-]  not the same with [wd3,-]  the kind we see nowadays.     The second part [wd3,2-3]  of the people is laboring people of whom Stephen and Sissy are the representative figures. They are oppressed by the capitalists, but they are so kind, honest and lovely.  Take Stephen for example, he is a worker in Mr Bounderby's factory, only one of the "hands" in Mr Bounderby's eyes, but he is able to taste the honey of love while Mr Bounderby and Mr Gradgrind have not a sense of it.  Now, let's see how the author describes the circus people: They were simple and gentle, like children.  There was a look of honesty in their eyes, and pity too.  They were the kind of  people who like to help others -- and do not count the cost. I appreciate the author's ability to see the goodness  of the laboring people.      The third part [wd3,2-3]  of the people I would like to name them "the middle part."  Louisa, Tom and Bitzer are the suffer [np6,6-]  of the society, but they don't have the characteristic [np6,4-4]  of the laboring people, on the contrary, some of them do harm to the people. [sn1,s]    As a matter of fact, through the three parts [wd3,2-1]  of people and the relationship among them, the author drive [vp3, 2-3]  home to us the situation of the capitalist society.  And through reading the novel, I found an important way to read, that is, to think of the background all the time you are reading a novel.

Although the explendid [fm1,-]Manderey was ruined, the love between Maxim and his bride was deepened.  They can built[vp4,2-]  a new house and begin their new life. Wish them happiness!

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 22><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                   Before we judge the boy we must remember the most important principle guilding [fm1,-]  a criminal court: the court must prove the accused person's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.  In other words [sn9,-]  the accused is held innocent until proved guilty.  In the murder case we can't prove the boy's guilty because so many reasonable doubts emerge and no one can explain them rationally: [sn9,-]   It seems to be quite possible for the boy to commit [vp1,-3]  murdering his father owing to the fierce conflict between them.  But the conflict isn't enough to prove he was inexorably [wd2,2-3]  to commit [np7,11-1]  murder. One and another one doubt suggest themselves.[sn,s].  No one, including the two main witnesses, could prove he's guilty .     As an important witness, the old man's testimony is unbelievable.  We can easily  pick up two obvious pick holes in his testimony.  Firstly [sn9,-]  he said that he heard the boy and his father quarrel fiercely in the upstairs department [wd1, 3-] . He heard the boy say to his father, "I'm going to kill you." A second later he heard a body falling.  It's said that at that moment an elevated train was passing by, which is [vp6,7-1] roaring past his nose.  The noise was too loud and awful for him, such an old man, to hear anything.  He told a lie.  Secondly, he claimed that when he heard the body fall, he got up and went down the hall to the front door.  He opened it and looked out in time to see the boy runing [fm2,-]  down the stairs.  The distance from his bed to the front door is sixty-three feet six inches.  How can an old man as [wd3,5-1]  him with two canes walk such a distance in 15 minutes?   He is a liar.  We can't believe a word he said.      As to another major witness who claimed that she saw the under commiting [vp5,4-] , we  can also pick up pick holes in her testimony.  She said she was unable to sleep that night and happened to look into the window which is [vp6,7-]  right across from hers across the EL track at top speed.  And she saw the boy stab his father.  A second later the lights went out.  She had no time to put on her glasses.  That's  for sure.  So it's impossible for her to see clearly what happened in the room where the murder took place.  Her testimony is also weak and doubtful.       Since no one and no evidence can prove the boy's guilty, he is innocent.
 
<ST 5> <SEX 2> <Y 8> <SCH Zhongda> <AGE 20> <WAY 3> <DIC 1> <TYP 1>            Christmas and Spring Festival     Christmas is the biggest and the best-loved holiday  in the West.  So is our lunar New Year.  The western holiday and our tranditional [fm1,-]  Spring Festival are much similar.     As the Christmas [wd4,3-1]  coming, cities and towns deck  their streets with bells, garlands of evergreens and glittering decorations.  On almost every front door hangs some red and green symbol of the Christmas season such as a fragrant evergreen bough tied with a red bow.  In China, you also feel the air of  New Year in the streets.  In my hometown, the trees, along the bank or lined [wd5,4-2]  the streetside, are strung with twinkling electric lights.  The shops hang the big red lanterns in front of the door [np6,11-] .  The buildings set up colourful frags [fm1,-]  waving in the wind.[sn,s].    Both the western people and eastern people are busy during the important holiday [np6,12-] .  The western people are busy in sending cards, buying Christmas tree [np6,5-] , trimming the tree [np6,7-]  and decorating the house [np6,10-] .  In my hometown, people are busy in buying new clothes, preparing things for  [np7,3-2]  new year.          Music literally fills the air at Christmas and [np7,-2]  Spring Festival.  Carols sung by church choirs, by school children express the joyous [wd2,2-2]  of people.  In my hometown the special songs sung in New Year are often heard from the recorder at shops, in [pp2,-1]  home [sn9,-]  while you are walking in [np7,2-1]  street.[sn,s].   Happiness fills everyone's heart.     Both Christmas and [np7,-2]  Spring  Festival are family festivals. Going home for Christmas  and going home for [np7,-2] Spring Festival are customs.  No distance seems too far away if it enables one to join the family circle for the holiday.  Parents welcome home their children and grandchildren.  On Christmas Eve, the family will has [vp4,3-]  a great meal including turkey, toasted duck, pies, [wd4,5-1]  puddings.  In our hometown, we also have the grand dinner on New Year's Eve including chicken, goose, [wd4,3-1]  fish.  We also make some special cakes for the New Year.     During the Christmas and [np7,-2]  Spring Festival, the children are the happiest group [wd5,4-] .  In the west [fm3,-] , the children receive the [wd5,2-2]  Christmas presents.  In China, children receive money from the older members in the family.   They go out in new clothes together to let off firecrackers and have a good time.    Comparing Christmas and [np7,-2]  Spring Festival, they both are the [wd5,3-3]  festivals for jubilation.

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 20><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                    Galileo is regarded as the father of the modern science.  No doubt that he had contributed a lot to the world.  After reading the text Galileo, the Stargazer Who Defied the World,  I have known more about this great man.  In my view, Galileo is a seeker and fighter.     Galileo is a seeker.  He devoted his whole life to seeking for the truth.  As a curious and observant boy, he was eager to probe the mystery of the world.  He never took anything for granted.  He found out the truth through his own experiments.  He himself devised tests to examine and prove his hypothesises [fm2,-]  and conclusions.  He had never believed any theory unless he found the facts to support [wd4,11-] .  Galileo's dedication to his pursuit of truth and his rebellion to Aristotle earned himself a great trouble at that Dark Ages.[sn,s].   But he insisted [vp1,-2]  his belief all along. Even when he was compelled to renounce his opinions, he didn't give up his experiments privatly [fm1,-]  and stuck to his belief in his heart.     Galileo is also a fighter .  As he was carrying out his experiments, he was fighting against the sneers of his students, he jealousy and hatred of his colleagues and the persecution of he Inquisition.  Undaunted by the antagonism of these people, Galileo continued his studies.  His keen belief on the truth gave him courage and power to fight against the prejudices.  He had succeeded.  Not only had he become famous at that time, but also his contribution to the science was approved today.     Galileo's story is far more than inform us the life of the great scientist.[sn,s].   It arouses our admiration for his sincerity to [pp1,1-2]  the science, his courage to the knowledge and his quality.[sn,s].

My Grandmother     My grandmother is a kind peasant woman.  She spends most of her life in the village.  Though she is little [wd3,2-1]  educated, she has a good sense. I used to live with her and my counsins [fm1,-]  when I was small because my parents were too busy to look after me . She takes good care of her grandchildren and gives them every comfort.  They all love her and she loves them also.    My grandmother had too much to do in running a house.  As our family was not wealthy, she had to do everything herself.  She got up the earliest in the morning and sleeped [fm2,-]  late at night.  She fed the pigs, chickens, ducks and geese, and watered the vegetables.  She prepared the meals and washed the clothes.  In the harvest season, she must help in the field.  She worked hard yet [wd5,3-2]  without complaining.     She is also a thrifty and industrious woman.  She saves every penny as she can.  As she had been [vp6,2-6]  busy ever since she was young, she looks older than she really is.  Her face is wrinkled, her hair turns silver white, and some of her teeth become movable [wd3,3-] .  But she works as hard as ever.  Though her grandchildren have grown up and the family condiction [fm1,-]  has improved, she refuses to do nothing.  Now she is still raising a group of chickens and planting a patch of vegetable.    Often she says to us, "Work while you work,  play while you play.  If you do not work, you will become lazy and of no use."  What good advice she has given to us!  She had just been [vp6, 3-8]  to school for several years but she taugh [fm1,-]  us how to act through her experience.  We must live up to it and always keep it in mind.

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 20><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                        The Defence Lawyer's Declaration     My client is innocent because he can't be proved to [wd5,4-1] guilty by the full evidences.  There are still reasonable doubts about the murder.     First, let's talk about the knife.  That's an unusual knife and the storekeeper have [vp3,2-1]  identified it and said it was the only one of its kind he had.  My client had bought the knife from him as a present to his friend.  Unfortunately, he lost the knife on the way home and it is the same as the one which was stabbed into his father by chance.  But it proved nothing.  Maybe there are then [fm1,-]  knives like that.  It is the only one in that store, but how about in the other junk shops?  So it can't proved [vp4,2-]   that only [ad1,-s] there is one knife in the case.  My client lost the knife and someone else stabbed his father with the knife just like it.     Secondly, let's review the testimony of the neighbour who lived under my client and his father's home.  He claimed after my client was beaten, he heard him yell, "I'm going to kill you. "  A second later, he heard the body falling.  And he saw my client running out of the house 15 seconds after that.  The man is [vp6,2-5]  lying.  He made himself believe he told the truth. Let's take a look at that picture.  When the murder happened,  a [np7,-1]  EL train passed the room in which the killing took place.  We proved that when our window was open and the train went by, the noise was so awful that we couldn't hear ourselves think.  We also proved [wd5,2-2]  have proved that it took at least 10 seconds for a train to pass a given point or two seconds per car.And we had another witness see the killing and the body fall through the windows of the last two cars of the five-car train.  So that EL train had been going by the man's window for at least 6 seconds before the body fell.  The man couldn't had [vp4,3-1]  heard my client's  saying "I'm going to kill you" while the front of the train was roaring past his nose.  He couldn't heard [vp4,2-4]  it with the noise.  But suppose he did hear it.How many times has [vp3,3-4]  each of you said "I'll kill you?" Probably, hundreds.  We say it every day but it doesn't mean that we're really going to kill someone. And do you think that my client would shout a thing like that so that the whole neighbour [wd3,4-2]  could hear?  Everyone is much too bright to do that.  On the other hand, the witness also said that he saw my client beat it downstairs 13 seconds after the killing.  It's impossible.  For you see, the witness is a man who can only walk very slowly with canes and he even needs help to get into the witness chair.  And when the killing happened, he was in bed in his room.  We have proved that if he wants [wd4,3-4]  reach the front door, he have [vp3,1-]  to get out of bed, get his canes, walk 12 feet to the bedroom's door, open it, walk 43 feet to the front door and open it.  How can it be possible for an old man like him to finish such a  long walk in 15 seconds. [sn9,-]   It take's [fm2,-]  at least 39 seconds for an old person with canes to walk 40 feet. It's been proved. So the man was trying to get to the front door and as [wd4,1-8]  heard someone running down the stairs, he assumed it was my client.     Thirdly, let's think of the downward angle of the stub wound. My client is five feet eight inches tall while his father was six two.  There is a difference of 6 inches.  It's very hard to stab down into the chest of someone who's taller than you are.  My client would have to move his hand above his shoulder.  Anyone  who's ever used a switch knife would never have stabbed  downhanded[fm1,-].  So my client wouldn't have made the kind of would [wd7,8-4]  to kill his father as he had some experience with the switch knives.     Fourthly, let's think over another's witness's declaration.  She said that she went to bed about 11 o'clock that night.  Her bed was next to the open window.  She could see right into the window across the tracks.  She tossed and turned for over an hour, unable to sleep.  Finally she turned towards the window at about twelve ten .  As she looked out, she saw my client knife his father.  I would say that she did see the murder through the window, but she couldn't have seen that  the murderer was my client.  She wears glasses.  Let's not forget it.  No one wears glasses to bed.  So she wasn't wearing glasses in bed while tossing and turning.  She looked out [wd4,3-2]  the window and saw the murder taking place and the light went out a second later.  She couldn't have time to put on her glasses.  What she saw was only a blur.  She just thought she saw my client kill his father.     Basing on the four reasonable doubts thereinbefore, I beg the jurors to turn over the case and vote my client not guilty.  That's all.  

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 20><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1>                                                                          Intensive Reading Before and Now      Before I began the study at my sophomore year, I did   worry about the courses, especially the [wd5,7-2]  intensive reading.       Intensive reading in freshman year was quite boring not only because the book was a little outdated, but because the way in which the teacher taught was so simple and direct.  All we had to do on this subject was to check out the new words in the text, and to listen to the teacher to analyse some grammar points in the text, and finally to finish the exercises of the text.    I'm [vp6,-5]  afraid, before the term began, that the procedure in intensive reading courses will [vp6,s-]  continue.     To my great joy, changes has [vp3,1-]  taken place in the subject.  The greatest one is that our teacher has changed the way of teaching. We now have to do a lot of preparation before the text [wd3, 2-1] begins.  We have to know something about the background, the characters, etc.  I thought that these [pr1,-1]  preparation would help us know further the details of the text and would enlarge our horizon [cc3,3-] , though  we have to spend more time and energy on the preparation.  I appreciated particularly the section our teacher leads us to speak.  I thought that learning to express the feeling in English was an important target for us especially when we were in sophomore year.  Though we sometimes were too shy to open our mouths and left our teacher in embarrassment, we indeed wanted to practise our oral English.     What I expected the intensive reading courses to be in the future is that we should do more discussions [cc3,3-]  in class and have more chances to open our mouths to speak English.  I thought that maybe both [np7,5-6]  teacher and students could think of some questions and delemmas [fm1,-]  for us to discuss. According to the details of the text, we can put us [pr4,3-1]  into the situation of the text, and think, if we are [vp8,s-]  the character in the text, what we will do [vp8,s-] .     In a word, the intensive reading course in my mind is a comprehensive course.    

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 20><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 2>  Character Sketch of Galileo    As a great scientist, Galileo posessess [fm1,-]  the character a scientist should have -- talence [fm1,-]  and perseverance.    When he was 18 years old, he observed the swinging of a lamp in a church by chance and discovered an important theory in the science history.  From this, we can tell that Galileo was a talented person with keen observation which should be the essential ability of a scientist.    But what made him a great scientist in history is, besides the talence [fm1,-] , his perseverance. [sn9,-]   In the period of time during which Galileo lived, religion occupied a powerful role [cc3,4-]  in the society religious authority stood beyond the government. [sn1,s] They owned their court and could judge whether a guy was vicious or not.  Under the pressure of the religion, many scientists had to bow before it, and gave up their belief.     Galileo was threatened by the Inquisition as well when he wrote a book and agreed with the viewpoint of Copernicus', but he didn't give in.  He tried his best to prove the theory and to persuade the Pope to accept his theory.     During the time from 1592 to 1610, Galileo moved to the University of Padua.  There, he got a free environment to continue his research.  He was successful at that time.    In 1610, Galileo gave up the comfortable and safe life in the University of Padua and went back to Pisa.  He tried hard to introduce his theory to the Inquisition but failed.    He was forced to obey the Pope's orders but continued his research secretly in very bad conditions.    Galileo's theory was admitted [cc3,4-]  by the Pope of Rome in 1979.  His perseverance got [wd3,2-1]  successful at last.   

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 20><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 2> 
My Dad     When I began to write this article, I wondered what information I would get from my memory about my father because, sometimes, Dad seemed so  strange to me.[sn,s].      What does my father look like?  Dad was [vp6,7-]  one of the most ordinary kind of people with few words.  The deepest impression about him in my mind  was [vp6,8-]  his always [ad2, 1-2]  rough  [wd3,-1]  face.  In my childhood, I was usually too scared to look [vp1,-1]  him in the face.  Each time when we were together, I just wanted to escape from him.         Common as he was, I wouldn't find anything particular about my father to brag before my classmates.  Sometimes I would feel shamed [wd3,3-3]  of his ordinariness.  I would ask myself whether I would choose to be his son if I had the chance before I was born.  Also, it seemed that he didn't care about me  much and just let me go my own way.  There must be a gap between us, I  always thought.     An episode happened and changed my perception [wd3,-] towards dad.  It was just after I had received the notice that I was accepted by Zhongshan University that a  banquet was held. All of my relatives came to congratulate me on it.  At [pp1, -2]  that night, I was  so surprised to find dad singing songs and talking loudly and excitedly all the time.  He wasn't the one he used to be.  What astonished me most was that father got drunk that night, for as  a bus driver, he never drank more than a little glass of beer.     I felt something unusual  about dad that night.  It seemed that something which he had hidden in his heart for a long time bursted [fm2,-]  out.  And I found the things I had neglected or so many years at [pp1,-2]  that night.    I knew he was proud of me, and I was proud to have a father like him as well.  I will be his son. Forever. 
  
<ST 5><SEX 1><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 21><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 1> 
In western countries, there has the first day of Xmas gift shopping [sn8,s]the shopping is on all day long, [sn8,s] street lights and store windows are decorated with the traditional Xmas colours of red and green. [sn1,s] Families  decorate [wd4,2-1]  home [wd3,2-3]  inside and outside after they had [vp6,8-3]  a spring cleaning.  During the time,  Xmas tree is very popular  because people think it can bring good luck, and then in every home, there is a beautiful Xmas tree decorated with coloured light [np6,9-] .  Sometimes, in many communities there is the costom [fm1,-]  of decorating a big Xmas tree for out-door display.       Before the Xmas Eve, most people exchange presents and send Xmas cards to their friends, relatives and bussineers [fm1,-]  associate [np6,6-] . On Xmas Eve or Xmas morning, many families go to Church, then they come home to enjoy a traditional Xmas dinner, which includes turkey, goose, ham, plum pudding, and mince  pie, sweets, and so on.  Before going to bed, children hang their stockings by [np7,5-1]  fireplace, hoping some sweets and toys will be given by Santa Claus.  At the same time Xmas is also a time for singing.  In [np7,1-1]  USA, especially Handel's Xmas choral [fm1,-]  music "Messsiah" are [vp3,5-1]  heard everywhere during the season over the radio,[sn8,s]   On [fm3,-]  TV or in department stores.          In a  word, it is a great occasion for children and all people with emphasis on love, and it is the most pleasant time of the year. To compare with the western Xmas, the chinese [fm3,-]   Spring festival [fm3,-]  exists the similar points, [s8,s] it is also the biggest chinese [fm3,-]  holiday. [sn1,s]On New Year's eve, each family has a great reunion dinner, and the peak of the celebration activities fall [vp3,6-4]  on New Year's Eve and the day after. For instance, the people will stay up till 12 o'clock, then they will cheer themselves up and burn the firecrackers [cc3,3-] , do some bless for [vp2,4-2]  each other, etc.  And on the day after -- New year's Day, all the family members dress in their finest and then go to visit their relatives or friends.      According to [np7,-2]  Chinese tradition, making jiaozi (dumplings) on the fifth day of the lunar Calendar will bring good luck in the new year.  Quickly, Spring Festival ends after the traditional Lantern Festival.  On the night of Yuan Xiao, also known as the Lantern Festival, [np7,-2]  Chinese custom calls for the display of Lanterns inside or outside of the homes [wd3,5-] , according to [np7,-2]  Taoist  belief, the Lord of Heaven visits the earth on the Lantern Festival to confer Luck and happiness on those who are morally upright. [sn1,s]    After reading all this [pr1,1-1]  things above might help you widen your horizon to know more about the western culture and the eastern one.[sn,s].                 

<ST 5><SEX 1><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 21><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 2> 
Galileo     Galileo  was born in Pisa, Italy in February, 1564.    He was the famous physicist all over the world when he was 19,he made his first important discovery-the Isochronism of Pendulum, by chance, which is applied today in the measurement of time, the eclipses of the sun, and the movement of the stars. [sn1,s]      Galileo had even been a professor of Mathematics in the University of Pisa.  During that time, he challenged the great Aristotle's theories by conducting an experiment regarding the laws of bodies in motion and got the famous theory that two different weights dropped simultaneously from the same height, would fall to the ground at the same time.     While in Padua, Galileo had written a book concerning the movement of heavenly bodies.  He favored Copernicus theory which declared that the earth is [vp6,5-2]  a planet which revolves [vp6,8-1]  around  a fixed sun.  For to do so, he was be delivered to the torture  Chamber of Inquisition.[sn,s].   Although he was compelled to renounce his belief, he didn't give up flighting [wd3,4-3]  with the Inquisition untill [fm1,-]  he died on January 8, 1642.He left the world he loved far better informed than it was when he entered it.

So before you consider which you are fit for, science or language, you have to know the different approaches to science and language.    Firstly, the ways of thinking are quite different in these two kinds of study.  You notice that science students usually consider the feasibity [fm1,-]  of things while language students firstly take his [pr1,5-]  own feeling [np6,6-],  like [np6,7-]  or dislike [np6,9-]  into consideration. However, as for language  study, you should be more sentimental [wd3,9-] .  Apart from vocabulary and grammar our should put your heart into the works, together with the author's heart, otherwise you can not share the feelings and thoughts with the author or preciate [fm1,-]  the works.     Secondly, language study demands a more pratical [fm1,-]  way than the study of science.  Because language is a tool  by [pp1,4-7]  which you communicate with the outside world, a [np7, -2]  efficient way for you to adquire [fm1,-]  the communicative skills is to use it as much as you can.  As for science study not that means you needn't try to apply the knowledge to the daily life,the present preeminent task is to have a deep understanding of the theories of your subject and do experiments to test them. [,s] [sn1,s]           Anyway all subjects have something in common. What's more, don't limit yourself in [pp1,3-5]  the field of your major and try to enlarge the horizon [cc3,3-] .  Remember knowledges [np5,1-3]  are always relative.  

<ST 5><SEX 2><Y 8><SCH Zhongda><AGE 21><WAY 1><DIC 1><TYP 2>                                                                                       The Sky at Twilight The lingering sun was now moving down in the west, red and  orangish.  No longer speaking like a shy girl, the sun looked so peaceful and composed.  Grandma and I was walking in the twilight, enjoying the sunset.  When I was a little girl.  I used to go out for a walk with Grandma after supper.  But after I went to high school, I had to spend more time on my study, and now, studying in Guangzhou, [sn3,-s]  the time to be with Grandma was getting less and less. [sn1,s]  I held Grandma by the arm and obviously felt that she was now an old woman.  Time had slowed her steps and bumped her back.  Several times when walking with me, Grandma turned to me and found surprisedly [fm2,-]that my shoulder was higher than hers.  Each time she laughed and said, "Oh, you see, I've got old.[sn8,s]. But it's rally a great thing to see you've grown up!  And it sometimes reminds me of the past time [wd5,5-]  when you were just little girls."    Every time Grandma said these, I always slipped back in time to my childhood and remember [vp6,10-]  many things  Grandma had told me when walking. Grandma was born in a small village.  As any other  girl in that village. [sn2, s-] She recieved [fm1,-]  no education and just did housework and farmwork all day long.  When reaching her early twenties, Grandma was married to Grandpa, who, [sn9,-]  she didn't ever seen [vp6,9-]  before. All the things were determined by thers[fm1,-], which people took for granted. Then, desterny [fm1,-]  made Grandma a joke [vp2,4-]  which was so serious that she could almost [wd3,7-3]  not bear it.  When Father was only 8 months old, Grandpa passed away and left them for ever [fm2,-] . t's hard to imagine the hardness Grandma encountered when she tried  to bring up Father by her own hands, standing some people's bully [cc3,4-] . Tilling the land was far from enough to make a liveing [fm2,-] .  After getting up early in the morning, Grandma climbed up the hill, wearing straw sandals and a little package containing some rice and a yam bean as lunch, cut the grass and then sell [vp6,26-]  them [pr1,6-]  in the market. Sometimes when she finished cuttitheirst was also in the twilight, Grandma stood up after bending for such a long time, gazed at the winding way [wd3,2-]  towards the hill top and found all her companies had family members to come to help them.[sn,s].[sn1,s] But Grandma, alone, stood in the glow of the sunset.  She was at a loss.  However, even so, Grandma never wanted Father to help her. She was not willing to take Father's time from his study.  To her, the greatest happiness was to see Father's good score.  In rainy days, Grandma also kept working.  She liked it most to watch Father studying while herself [pr4,1-2]  was spinning [fm2,-] .  No matter how hard it was, for better or worse [wd7,3-], Grandma determined [vp1,1-4]  to ring up  Father, gave him education and let him step out of the  poverty-stricken land. Grandma's dream came true after enduring for over 20 years. She came to town with my parents and life was getting better and better.  And then my sister and I came to the world.  Since then, Grandma had put her heart into us. But I knew Grandma sometimes still felt loss [wd2,1-]  .  Of cause [wd3,1-] , it was not the same as she felt many years ago.  When the whole family got together, apart from chitchat, my parents, my sister and I usually talked about the [wd5,2-1]  litterature [fm1,-] , current events and things we learned from TV, radio, newspaper [np6,-2]  and magazines.  But for most of the things we talked about, Grandma could not understand.[sn8,s]    In these cases, she always sat quietly, nothing to say.  I had thought that it was only indifference about what she could not understand.  However, Only [fm3,-]  when I went out for a walk with Grandma one day after supper, [sn9,-]  did I went [vp4,2-] into the depth of her heart.  When we were walking, she told me sentimentally that although the sky at twilight was beautiful, it meant the end of a day.  And then, I tried to understand her inner feeling [np6,2-] .  It was [np7,-2]  same kind of self-contradicsion [fm1,-]  -- she was so happy to see the children were no longer like her, uneducated on the other hand, she felt inferior and lonely.  From then on, we always tried [vp6,5-]  to keep her company. "Look! How beautiful the cloud looks! " Grandma's remark drew me back in time. I should cherish the chance to see the beauty of dusk with Grandma. "To tell the truth, when your sister get [vp6,3-3]  married, I felt a little loss [wd2,4-] .  But how fast the [wd5,2-2]  time flies!   Now I'll be a great-grandma! [sn1,s] "Grandma, you'll be busy again.  I know you're always likeing [fm2,-] [vp6,4-]   to keep yourself busy." So, I'll never be lonely."
